The 2D platformer, distilled to its core, and perfected. Coming from other platformers the physics can come off as weird, but once you get the hang of it, movement becomes a fluid smooth dance. Wonderful level design, squeezing so many possibilities out of a single screen limitation. Frictionless retries, encouraging you to go and go until you crack a path. 
The core is good, yes, but just as important is what's around it. 4,340 levels, split across solo, co-op, and race, plus a level editor and online catalogue. Amazing soundtrack that ranges from microhouse to industrial to ambient. Lots of fun unlockables to keep you going.

If you love 2D platformers, or even just like them, this is a necessity. It is perfection. 5 Stars.

N++ is a game that has limitless potential but is severely held back by terrible design choices in level design. This game is a thumbs up for anyone that does not decide to collect all the gold in the various levels of the game or trophy hunt in it. 

Its levels like "its full of stars" and "Lunatic machine"  that lack any sort of self awareness of what type of game you are playing. The developer of that level was more concerned with making a "cool" looking level rather than a functioning one. This is one of many examples and it is mind wrenching that they would allow levels like that to make it to the final product. 

The momentum based jumps feel arbitrary and RNG based with barely any player control. Levels will stick gold in very questionable spaces that feel more like a way to recycle content than to keep a player challenged, and half the time the "Challenge" seems more like you are just rolling the dice every life to collect all the gold , for there are too many factors in place to stay alive in such a hectic environment. You will die many many times with no lesson learned and the game feels like it is hard to just BE hard, with no system in place for real improvement. This is obviously based on the levels you are playing, however.  

The main issue with this game is the momentum based movement is very rewarding when pulled off but the developer made levels that slow the pace down to a screeching halt and make the player slow down in an environment meant to be quick.

 I mean for F&%^'s sake the story is about a FAST ninja. Not a slow one. 
6/10, still fun but , it makes you want to pull your hair out and becomes less fun and rewarding over time. And therefore I cannot recommend it. 

The music is fire, tho.

This is unironically one of the best pure-gameplay games ever made. My absolute favorite.

The controls are perfect, and also perfectly deterministic as are the enemy/hazards, so every single attempt on a level you'll get the same results with the same keypresses. Every mistake is your own fault. 

It was fun flying through the regular completion of levels and then they started getting harder, taking minutes to figure out, then eventually i'd hit some really hard levels that took hours. These hard levels start every single time, with me going THIS IS IMPOSSIBLE, but every 10 minutes that passed, I notice myself getting better and better and more perfect on pulling off the movement that I learned to eventually beat the stage. The longer the grind to learn a level, the more nervewracking then satisfying it is when I pull it off.

And the challenge system too, it's so brilliantly integrated... such an easy addition per level from the game designer, instantly gives each level 2 to 10 times as much replay value. I can choose on a play session to progress uncleared levels, to progress cleared levels i need full gold on, or to progress gold levels I need the challenges on. And then those completions unlock yet even more levels that are on their own godly tier.

This old-school action/puzzle platformer dates all the way back to the early Flash days, with several earlier inceptions.  If you know the classic N, N++ offers the same and more.

The good:  Most of the hard-as-nails platformers that proliferated in the 00's are derived in some way from this game, at least on the surface.  Speed, jumping, walljumping, wallsliding, and dodging deadly traps.  It doesn't get any purer than the N formula.  No frills, no secrets, no anything but solid action.  There are awards for acquiring all the gold and beating an entire 25-room episode on a single timebar.  Several additional play modes, such as co-op and race, enhance the experience.  The I/O performance is also excellent, lacking the random frame drops of the earlier Flash versions.

The bad:  The same as the good.  No frills, no secrets, and incredibly frustrating difficulty at times.  The shear amount of content (i.e. extremely difficult content) means this one will frustrate even completionists.  For less-skilled players, the need for beating five rooms at once in order to advance means the game will infuriate those who can't beat just one room in the set.  Also, once you've played some of N, there isn't much more to it.  What you see is all you'll ever get.

As stated, the 'bad' is sparse, while the 'good' is thick.  N++ is a must-have for your collection.

Proof that a game can be so simple yet so good. N++ is the third installment of the "N" series which started as a flash game in 2004. Each level takes place on one screen and the player has to acquire a key, and then navigate to the level's exit before the time limit runs out. The only way to increase the time limit is to collect gold scattered around the level. While the one screen limit may seem too restrictive, the developers have done a great job of cramming them full with challenging but fair obstacles to overcome. Each enemy or obstacle will always have a pattern or clearly be telegraphed. The player will have to complete an "episode" which comprises of five levels before they can unlock even more levels to beat. There are literally hundreds of levels to play (not to mention the additional multiplayer episodes with a plethora of different modes to chose from) and with the built in level editor, players will never run out of stuff to do. But something that'll keep you playing until the end is N++'s razor sharp controls. Maneuvering through each level is a joy since you control your character so effortlessly, although momentum is something you must keep in mind. Meaning if you don't have enough speed while climbing up a wall or clearing a large gap, while not impossible, will pose to be more difficult. Overall N++ is a magnificent platformer with loads of content to enjoy, and not to mention tons of secrets to find. Cons:

If you in any way enjoy tough platformers, or consider yourself a fan of indie titles such as Super Meat Boy, this is a must-buy.
There are few games which have this much content on Steam. You probably read the description or watched the trailer and thought that there can't possibly be this many levels in the game. Well, there is, and not to spoil anything, but the 2360 levels are actually just scratching at the surface of the mass of secrets and challenges that are in this game. You will eventually come to realise (if you are patient enough), the layers of complexity that go into every one of those levels. Good luck getting 100%.
As for the co-op levels, they're great, and up to the standard of the solo levels. But there is one glaring problem that stops almost everyone from getting to enjoy a significant portion of the content in N++. I for one don't know anyone in real life that is actually interested in playing this game, so the lack of an online multiplayer is seriously damaging to this game. It seems like a massive waste of time for the devs ; to create all these levels for multiplayer, but fail to add the one thing that is essential for most people.
Still, this game provided me a good 70 hours of enjoyment and I am only at 42% completion. Worth a buy at full price, and it's a bargain on sale.

[b] N++ [/b] is a minimalist hardcore platformer about a ninja collecting gold. Yeah, there's not much in the way of the story, but this game makes up for that in droves with its flawless, fluid, and extremely polished controls and levels that will keep you playing for [i] hours. [/i] The momentum is flawless, and the levels are brutally difficult yet pretty fair. The graphics are minimal, with no clutter that would distract you. So much polish and care went into every little detail, with the main menu showing recordings of your previous faliures, loads of hidden levels and secrets, and various options for completion. If you enjoyed Super Meat Boy, Dustforce DX, or other similar platformers, you need to buy this [i] immediately[/i]. 

[b] Pros: [/b]
+Great (but not perfect!) soundtrack
+Tight, fluid controls
+Intuitive and slick momentum 
+Simple and effective visuals
+Alternate color palettes and color customization
+No loading times, at all
+Lightning-fast restarts after failure
+Difficult but (mostly) fair levels
+Cooperative multiplayer mode
+Competitive multiplayer mode
+Can play singer player levels with multiple players
+A singleplayer time trial / multiplayer race mode
+Leaderboards
+Level editor with cross-platform sharing and downloading of levels
+Loads of care and detail to various elements throughout the game

[b] Cons: [/b]
-No story, but that barely matters
-A few levels in particular stand out as feeling like unfair difficulty spikes, but are still manageable

[b] Other notes: [/b]
~VERY hard throughout, only for those that can handle challenge in their games
~Seriously, it's [i] hard[/i].
~You [i] will [/i] die.
~And then die again.
~And again.

[b] tl;dr: [/b]
It's a tight and difficult platformer similar to Super Meat Boy. Clean visuals and controls. Be prepared to die over and over again. Worth your money ten times over. [i] Plus plus. [/i]
best game

N++ is the sequel to N+, which is the sequel to N. If you haven't played N, go play it now: it's a classic of the genre, one of the best things ever made in Flash, and it's also free, so you can think of it as the "trial version" of this game. The core gameplay hasn't changed at all.

However, N++ is a complete improvement on the original: it takes everything that was good about N and refines it. The controls are snappier. The graphics are sharper. The collison detection is even more impeccable. The level design is better, and the new enemies are a joy a play with, as are the cooperative and competitive level sets.

And the soundtrack. Oh god, the soundtrack: it is simply amazing. That is all.

I would highly reccomend N++ to anybody who enjoyed the original N. If you didn't like that game, there won't be anything for you here.

Has it really been 10 years since I've played the original N game back in 2006? Good god, time really flies. I knew I had to instantly buy this on launch to support the developers, as a thank you for all the free entertainment years ago.

The original Flash version kept me entertained for hours on end...to be more specific, it's a combination of euphoria and frustration. But usually frustration. 
Specifically, frustration at my own lack of skill. This game requires a lot of precision, even more so than [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/40800/]Super Meat Boy[/url], in my honest opinion. But the euphoria experienced from finally beating one of those almighty challenging levels is just incredible.

Floaty ninja jumping, sweet walljumping, amazing physics engine. Seriously - this has the best physics engine I've ever experienced in any 2D game ever. Maybe even 3D? I don't know if I want to go that far.
Those were key aspects to its underground cult following back then - these are key aspects in its successful sequels today. N+ and N++ helped to fine tune and overly polish the experience.

No online multiplayer? I don't see this as a problem. The original N never had any online multiplayer. N+ had it, but it would be a challenge to implement here because of latency and whatnot interfering negatively with the physics, that I can recognise. As a compromise, there is local multiplayer.

A vastly challenging experience, not for the faint-hearted (and that is about the only possible con I see in this, that the difficulty could put off the most casual gamers). A LOT of handcrafted levels (and even more user-created levels). Great colour palettes. I've been following N since it first came out on PC. For the most part, this is a fantastic edition of a fantastic core game.

N++ is an energetic platformer that focuses on momentum above all else. Your score bleeds away every second and collecting gold increases the score. Technically if you run out of time you lose, but I have yet to encounter any levels that make that the serious threat it was in the original game.

Most levels are less about whether or not you can complete the challenge (though some levels are hard enough for that to be a struggle) and more about how efficiently you can complete it. Few games have as engaging a sense of motion for me. This game captures the exhiliration of movement as well as a digital game can, and does so in two dimensions with minimalist artwork. It is an outstanding acheivement.

The soundtrack is hit and miss for me, but the wide variety of artists and tracks is impressive and when it hits it *really* hits. The interface is slick, the color skins are slick, the presentation is all around top-class though it would be nice to have a few more ways to view the leaderboards more arbitrarily.

And now we come to my few complaints. Perhaps I'm suffering from selective memory but I feel like I encountered a wider variety of challenges and a wider mix of enemy types across playing the original levels. User-made levels can help make up for this, and there's a tightness of composition to the levels that really shines in places ... but sometimes that same tightness makes it that much clearer how to efficiently move through the level. More levels now feel like pure rote practice as opposed to having a bit of exploration and experimentation followed by rote practice to get the method you discovered down. Perhaps I've just played too muhc N, but I can figure out most of the tricks to the new levels the second the level starts and there are fewer "aha" moments as I encounter the weird quirks of the level's design at exactly the wrong moment.

On the one hand there are also fewer filler levels of just collecting gold pieces and going to the exit without substantive threat ... but on the other hand I've never found myself pressed for time in the later levels of an episode because I didn't do the earlier levels efficiently enough and that feels like as much a loss as a gain. Further, many levels that would otherwise occupy that filler level space in the original game merely add a rocket launcher or a chaser to make things significantly more challenging without being significantly more interesting.

But those are minor issues and I can fix them by jumping back to the original whenever I feel like it or by exploring user-made levels for either edition of the game. N++ is still one of the best platforming games I've ever played and the best game I own for exploring the joy of motion from the comfort of home.

Cons:

It's funny that there's still an audience for games as simple as [i]N++[/i]. With the tech available to game developers now, one would think there'd almost be an expectation to make hyper-realistic and fluidly animated third-person cover shooters that probably only run at a cinematic 24 frames per second on most computers. The appeal of a 2D platformer is that it is - and almost always will be - extremely self-explanatory. Upon launching N++, it will take most people under 30 seconds to have everything figured out. It's the age-old mantra of 'easy to learn, hard to master' that so many genres will simply never be able to get right.

That said, it could be argued that the reason [i]N++[/i] is so simple to learn is because of its apparent fear of doing anything to differentiate it from the rest of the genre as a whole. To hone in on the problem, one should look to the previous instalments of the series. Originating as a free 2004 browser game, simply titled [url=http://www.thewayoftheninja.org/nv2.html][i]N[/i][/url], the title was later released as on Xbox Live Arcade as [i]N+[/i], including the addition of a well-received online multiplayer component. With the release of [i]N++[/i], it becomes pretty clear that developer Metanet Software isn't going to budge. The obscure titling begs the question: is this a sequel or a remake? The fact that all the levels are different per game says sequel, but the fact that the gameplay is perfectly identical screams 'stand-alone DLC'. Which is truthfully what [i]N++[/i] probably should have been. It shows no characteristics of an entirely new game, and doesn't feel like a great investment if you've already played the previous two games.

By itself, [i]N++[/i] is a great game. The gameplay is smooth and the minimal graphic style is sleek and professional. As with the previous games, it strikes a solid balance between fair and frustrating, and the local multiplayer modes are a blast with friends, including a tough-as-nails co-op mode in which both players are all but required to play at peak performance to complete the specifically designed levels. Race mode is by far the most enjoyable, as it lends an element of speedy precision that's missing from the solo levels thanks to a jump button so floaty that it's practically a feature.

The acclaimed online multiplayer is notably absent this time around, and criticism by fans was met with excuses stinking of the procrastinatory air that hangs over the product. It feels like the words 'can't be bothered' must have been uttered frequently during development, because it is quite literally a shiny new coat over an 11-year-old game that can still be played for free online. [i]N++[/i] gets a tentative recommendation, although there has to be a point where one does have to wonder if such a thing is worth playing, because have no doubt about it - you have seen all of this before.

I had dabbled in the original N back in the early 2000s when some person had uploaded it to AddictingGames, and I had a good time with it, though my 8 year old mind couldn't figure out how to beat a good chunk of the game. Years later, I think around 2010, I had pretty much forgotten about it. However, while browsing my local GameStop, I noticed a small DS game called N+. I immediately remembered my time playing the original flash game, and picked that box up to bring to the counter immediately. It was full of great danger, a tough challenge, and even had the original flash graphics as an option (or at least a replica that the DS could actually pull off). I spent hours on that game, and it's still one of my favorite DS games, and what I considered the gold standard of pure platformers.

Now we have another N game, which I immediately jumped on the opportunity to buy the second I found out about it (by selling a bunch of TF2 and Dota stuff that I don't use). I'll be comparing this to N+ DS a lot since that's the one I have the most experience with, so when I mention N+, it'll be referencing the DS version and not the PSP or 360.

I am definitely enjoying this game so far, and for the sake of information, I'll repeat the same shit everyone else has said. The controls are dead on, I use an Xbox 360 controller to play and it reads all my button inputs perfectly. It's a bit annoying that I can only navigate menus with the D-Pad since gameplay and the level editor allow/require the joystick(s) respectively.

The music is nice, though I found myself having to mute it after a while due to the style while wearing headphones. It's not the music's fault, I just get a headache if I listen to that kind of pumping EDM stuff for too long, so I play with headphones off. It would be awesome if I could add in music from my own library or if the music from all the versions of N+ (but mainly the DS version ^_^) were in the game as unlockables, or even DLC if need be (I'd pay for the DS music in a heartbeat).

The legacy episodes are nice too. I noticed a few levels from N+ on the in some of the episodes I haven't unlocked yet, though with the physics being closer to the original N than N+.

Now for my gripes:

- No Tag or Domination multiplayer modes for us DS ninjas. I loved Domination in N+ and I'd love to see it return so I could do that without needing someone else to have their own game card. I have no real problem with no online multiplayer since I don't care much for online in a game like this. If it gets added in at some point, that's all well and good, but I just want my Domination mode back. :'(

- The initially ran slower on my computer than it should, but I was able to fix it. Apparently turning off V-Sync fixes the problem, though it didn't initially work for me. I ended up fumbling with the window size a bit, and when I re-fullscreened it, [b]BAM![/b] Glorious full speed. 

- This is pretty minor, but the level editor has a lot fewer possible blocks than the DS version. Seriously, the kinds of shapes you can create in N+ DS is crazy. I actually tried to re-create one of my old custom levels and I had to make a lot of changes because the shapes I used don't exist in this version.

- To my knowledge, you can't set the graphics to the original flash graphics, I just don't see the same charm in these new graphics that I do in the simple flash graphics. I had similar feeling towards the Plus graphics in the DS version, but I could swap to the original graphics in that. Some of color schemes are also a bit too colorful for my tastes, but there are enough of them to mitigate that issue.

Other than those, this game turned out pretty good. I'll probably update this review later and give a much more informed opinion after I've cleared at least half the episodes. I still like N+ more, but once I've spent more time on this game, that opinion has a chance to change.

EDIT: Still like the DS version more, but this is still damn good.

N has been a series I've followed since around 2006, where I would secretly play it during class. The game was pretty special back then since it was made in flash, yet it was so well made and content rich that it could of passed as a AAA title at the time. Flash forward to 2016 with the release of N++ and it still holds strong as being one of the best platformers out there.

N++ is the best version of N, being the most polished and content rich of the series, but what makes this game truely special is something that has existed since the first version of N, that being its very well executed movement mechanics. N was a game that focused purely on platforming, there's basically no story, no abilities, no player gimmicks, no killing enemies (they're are plenty of enemies to kill you however). It's just you and your ability to run, jump and wall jump.

The movement in N++ is best described as "floaty" which to most is a word associated with bad platformers, yet N++ some how manages to make you feel almost completely in control with it's fast, precise and complex movement system. All your actions in N++ are influenced by multiple factors including speed, momentum and even the angle of the surface you are on. As a result, N++ takes a lot of practice to master and even some of the best players still haven't mastered the movement.

If you haven't figured it out yet, N++ is hard, like really, really hard, to the point that it could be ranked as one of the most difficult games of all time. While levels start out fairly simple, they quickly become more and more difficult as the game throws more obsticles, enemies and keeps mixing and matching them to make over 4000 handcrafted levels, and most of these levels are actually carefully crafted. Which leads me to my first complaint about this game which is while the levels are for the most part pretty well made, there are a few here and there which kind of feel "chaotic". While everything in N++ is in theory predicable, you'll find that there are just some levels where you have to just create and memorize a pattern of movements to get past them, there is very little room for adaptation and as a result some of these levels start to feel like a chore rather than an enjoyable challenge.

The artstyle in N++ is appropriately, minimalistic with several unlockable colour palettes to change things up a bit. For the most part, the artstyle is appealing with most of the colour palettes, however there are some odd ones here and there which are terrible to look at, for example a hot pink and orange colour palette which is really painful to look at, or a palette with colours that make it hard to see some obsticles and enemies. Aside for that, the artstyle is quite appealing when the right colours are used. Also don't worry, you can change colours anytime.

The music in this game is pretty good. Most if not all of the music is chill electronic music composed by several different artists. All of the soundtracks are about equal in quality and they suit the mood and gameplay of N++. There's only 2 songs I'm not a fan of but thankfully you can change the music at anytime.

As for other features in N++, there's a full fledged level editor and browser, so there is more or less infinite levels to play (though much like games such as Mario maker there is a lot of bad levels). Also there's 4 player local coop which I haven't played, but does have it's own set of challenges centered around having 2 or more players.

Overall, if you're a fan of N or a fan of difficult platformers, then N++ is something I would 100% recommend to you. It offers some of the most challenging and satisfying platforming in the genre, and it has 100s, possibly 1000s of hours of content. If you're still unsure about this game, then you can always try the online flash version which is free.

Wasted potential. The controls of this game are fluid and crisp, and the movement feels very liberating.

However, a huge majority of the levels are within confined spaces and require you to move very precisely to avoid instantly dying, which completely goes against the feeling the controls give me. I don't feel like a ninja at all, I feel like I'm trying to pick a lock in Skyrim every second level.

"But why don't you just play the open levels?"
Because you can't succeed at a level set unless you finish all five levels in a single sitting, that's why. This is what kills it for me. The great feeling you get when beating a really difficult level is completely counteracted when you're met with another, even more difficult level right after it, and you know that if you don't knuckle down and suffer through that one (and potentially up to three more after THAT) you're going to have to start the level you just beat all over again from the beginning.

The graphics are nice, the controls are nice, the music is nice, but the gameplay will give you nothing more than a free rage game on kongregate. If you want to rage, play Getting Over it with Bennett Foddy. If you want a good platformer, get SpeedRunners. Bennett Foddy is a better rage game because you'll never lose progress just for restarting the game, and SpeedRunners is nice because it rewards precision AND allows freedom of movement and momentum conservation.

I remember playing the origional N when it was a Flash game back in 2004/2005. It was one of my favorite Flash games at the time. It was a smooth, simple, fun and quite challenging platformer, and still is. N+, which I've never played, appears to be a console and handheld version of N. 

Now we have N++, an improved version of N, but for modern consoles and PC, with a level editor built in. It contains an incredible amount of levels, and even (if I'm not mistaken) all classic levels from N, as well as 'Ultimate' levels. All in all we're talking thousands of levels. Tens of thousands if you include community levels.

N++ is a good game, but can be frustrating at times. Balance is a bit weird, in that some levels that are very easy to beat will be very difficult when it comes to getting all the gold in said level. However this is not unusual for gaming. 

Some levels you will have to play hundreds of times to not only beat it but get all the gold, if that is your thing. What may take you 10 seconds to beat may take you an hour just to get all the gold without dying.

Overall a decent title.

You are a ninja. Your goal is to exit the level by collecting gold and avoiding enemies, mines and other possible entities. The game's difficulty can range from really easy for causal players, to excruciatingly painfully difficult for those hardcore players. So no matter what your skill is, you can still enjoy this game. Just to warn you about beating everything: This game is HUGE! Over 4000 levels are currently in the game, pluss an infinite amount of user created levels, so there's pretty much no end to this game.

There's also a co-op mode and a race mode for up to 4 players. Unfortunately at this time, there is no online co-op which is my only disapointment.

Overall, I highly recommend this game.

[h1]Metanet Software's N++ ----- Pure nostalgia circa 2001 to present :D[/h1]

A well deserved Thank-You to Mare & Raigan and their programmer(s) for creating this amazing game! 

In early 2001, N initially started off as a free and very fun downloadable flash game created ground up by two people [i](Seriously it's just two people who made this happen!)[/i] Fast forward more than a decade to find N++ as one of the great hidden gems in the platform genre. And to this day, the devs continue to add content while aiding with bug fixing when necessary. 

It's also worth mentioning N++ was released for console as well. So no matter if you rather play on console or PC, It's a Win-Win for anyone who enjoys those difficult & rewarding platformer experiences!

SOLO:
The perfect platformer. It has no fat on it. There are no flaws. The only flaw in this game is the flaw you have as a player, that prevents you from beating the next level. It is all based on whether or not you can perform. Every win is proof that you can win next time. Every failure is just the first step to winning. It has style, the level names are clever and punny, manipulating enemies is gratifying. There's too much packed into this game to summarize, and nothing that shouldn't be there is present. 10/10.

LEVEL EDITOR:
Easy and simple as making pumpkin pie during the holidays. Follow the instructions, and then if you want to, get creative. The recipies for your levels are waiting for you to discover them.

IRRELEVANT PERSONAL OPINION:
This game taught me a very important lesson about life, believe it or not. I was playing through the E-row on the N++ levels page, trying to beat them all to get to the secret levels. Every time I would start a new E-row episode, I would play through it and get to the final level absolutely furious. I could not beat the final level to these episodes. It was very frustrating at first. Many times I literally pulled my hair out. But, what I learned was this, since this game does not save your progress in episode, if you give up on the final level, you cannot continue where you left off. You have to play through the entire episode again. This taught me to finish strong, to see things through. If you give up at the end, your progress means nothing and it was all in vain. It's helping me complete my work and studies on time, to be honest.

Also, this game has a ton of nostalgia for me too, because I've been playing this game for about 8 years now, since the first flash version showed up on flash game websites. So that aspect of it is enjoyable too.

TL;DR:
This game is the best platformer you will ever play, it tops Super Meat Boy and the original Mario and Sonic games as well. Just play it and you'll see just how high the standard should be for this genre.

Definitely good, and when it's hitting, it feels fantastic. The only reason my recommendation is kind of tenuous, more of a decent to strong 6 than the 8 or 9 this game easily could have been is that the devs and I seem to disagree about what makes their game fun to play. 

The best levels, in my opinion, are huge, sprawling playgrounds where the main challenge is balancing between going fast enough to outrun enemies and make gigantic, screen-clearing leaps but not gaining *so* much ninja momentum you splatter yourself on the ground when you land. There are a good handful of these, and when you have the space to improvise somewhat as you loop around and around dodging missiles and grabbing gold bricks, it feels so fun and skilful that the game is worth it for them alone. 

However, there's another broad genre of level that feels like it's designed to appeal to the absolute psychopaths who like long boss runs in Soulslikes. You see a common pattern where the level can be completed yawn-inducingly trivially if you ignore the collectables, but if you're trying to 100 percent it, there are several dozen to easily a hundred plus of them to be grabbed. This on its own I don't have a problem with. Where I draw issue is that these levels seem to be consistently balanced around the fact that let's say 95 of those collectables require 6 / 10 skill at the game to collect - you need to pay full attention but you'll get them all no problem within the first attempt or two - and then there are maybe 5 or 3 or just one little gold brick that's been lovingly placed in a spot where to collect it you need to pull off an 11 / 10 3-second long, multi-step, frame-perfect, pixel-perfect butterfly kiss with an instant death trap. That's just not an interesting form of difficulty to me. It feels like I'm emptying the dishwasher but there's exactly one fork that needs to be put away inside the mouth of a rabid wolf who lives on the divider of a 6-lane freeway. Not 100 percenting the level feels like you're not getting your money's worth or even like you're being subtly mocked because it's so easy, and actually getting there doesn't feel good because it's mostly balanced around the insanely difficult 1 percent of the level not making you so jittery or tilted you fuck up the relatively easy part you can clear in your sleep. 

That said - if that kind of grind appeals to you, or you're more capable of just letting go and not feeling compelled to beat stuff like that, you'll probably love this game through and through. Even if you're like me - there is plenty here to love, plenty of levels that feel fair to lose and fun to master. I just wish it was more consistent.

N++ is the third major iteration on the N formula, and this one adds more than ever. New enemies, levels, flavours, four-player single-screen coop... But really, N has always been about that cathartic zen state you go into as you elegantly glide through levels... or blow up in glorious fireworks. Either way, the instantly-rethemeable UI and (mostly) soothing music imparts some zen from the game directly into YOU. Because ninjas are just that sneaky.

The only thing really missing is a visualisation/replay of every failed attempt at once when you finally do beat a level, Super Meat Boy style. These sorts of precision platformers make that kind of retrospective so satisfying to watch, what with the dozens or even hundreds of attempts a particularly hard level might take you.

Perhaps a feature that'll make it into N+++ (I jest).

N++ is the greatest platformer I've ever played, and that's coming from someone who gravitates towards platformers. If you're looking for great storytelling, art, or music, this game is not for you. But the gameplay? Well, I'm over 1300 hours into my more-or-less casual playthrough of N++ as I write this, and I'm still having a ton of fun.

Most players will play a couple hundred levels, and then drop the game, an experience which I still think is well worth it. (Especially since N++ is often heavily discounted during sales!) The truly dedicated will complete a full levelset or more, and perhaps try to collect most of the gold in the game. The nature of N++ is that as long as you're still enjoying the game, there will be more levels to play, gold to collect, or challenges to overcome.

If you played N back when it was a flash game, know that the controls and level design have improved considerably. If you're turned off by the extremely simplistic style, know that it's to reduce visual noise, so that the gameplay is even better. And if you've heard of N++ only as a difficult platformer, know that there are hundreds of levels in the game which are approachable even to a novice. I seriously cannot recommend N++ enough, and I think anyone who enjoys platformers owes it to themself to give this game a shot.

There isnt another platformer quite like n++, just like there isnt another quite like dustforce or celeste or the end is nigh. This is (in my opinion) by far the best platformer of its specific flavor; however, what makes this one really stand out is that it simply never ends. If I ever get that platforming itch, n++ is always there to scratch it. There is always another level to play, one more secret to find, even a hundred hours in.
It may seem like a brutal game to tackle with any sort of completionism in mind, but put that out of mind and it becomes quite comfy. Who knows? Maybe eventually you'll finish more difficult levels than you thought possible.
The multiplayer level design is also incredible. I may not have much to compare it to, but me and a friend had a great time grinding through the co-op levels every once in a while.
Yes, the menus and unlocks are somewhat buggy, but that doesn't effect the actual playing experience whatsoever.
The heavy, floaty physics aren't for everyone, but the amount of control that it gives you to dodge the constant barrage of missiles mines and shadow ninjas is unparalleled in any other platformer. 
While Celeste and its mods are still my favorite platformer, n++ is the best at what it does and will always keep me coming back for more.

I write this as I intend to lessen the grip this game has had on me, having owned it since the COVID lockdowns and playing it on and off since then, I doubt I'll ever find a game this rich in content and heart.

From completing the levels in solo mode, of which there are over 2000, to competing for top scores with the best players in the world on those very same levels, to making my own levels and playing levels (and entire tabs!*) made by others - the game is only as difficult, fun or frustrating as you want it to be. The pick-up-and-play nature of the game also lends itself well to that.

The minimalist style, the tight controls and the and the banger soundtrack (RIP Om The Def) all combine to leave you in a trance as you collect gold piece after gold piece and have your limbs fly across the map when you've grazed a mine.

Things do get extremely challenging towards the end, and that brings about another skill that you have to master: your mental fortitude. I can only speak for myself, but every death was an extra bit of motivation, and of course there was rage. The game will do that to you, but it's so weird to think about because after all what do you get in return for all that effort? 1 or 2 points out of 10565? You start to question whether what you did was even worth it. It's a question only you as a player can answer, and depends on the experience you want out of this game.

Special shoutout to the community, without which I would have never have made it as far as I did in my pursuit of Solo Completion, which I did end up achieving! Perhaps the 100% will come someday.

It truly can be the only game you play if you want it to be, there'll always be something there for you.

*Join the discord server!

[Introduction - skip straight to pros & cons for my opinions]
N++ is the long-awaited final sequel to N, the classic momentum-based Flash platformer released in 2004. You move around in a 2D plane, as you might expect from a platfomer, but perhaps more unusually every level is contained within a single screen and as such no side-scrolling is present. Every level is a static piece of art aside from some rather deadly enemies which move according to simple and predictable rules yet are often used in deviously challenging ways.

You control a stickfigure ninja with a wealth of different moves despite only having three buttons of control - left, right and jump. This is because he interacts with the environment in a physically simulated way and the same inputs will cause different effects depending on whether you're touching a floor, a slope, a wall or nothing at all. Mastering these interactions and the changes in the player's momentum that follow is key to surviving the increasingly difficult challenges the game throws at you. 

And oh boy are there many challenges. The game sports more than 2000 levels, many of which have additional challenges that will take even the most experienced veteran of the game hours to beat. If you ever run out of official content to play (unlikely) there are also highscore leaderboards to compete on and a great level editor with online level sharing.

Pros:
+the most satisfying movement mechanics in all of gaming
+massive amount of content
+no skill ceiling
+welcoming community
+beautiful visuals with lots of color options

Cons:
-updates have been slow so far (as of November 2016)
-I'm not a fan of the soundtrack

Conclusion: This is my favorite video game of all time. If you're into platformers you owe it to yourself to try it.

N++ is the latest in a series of physics based single-screen platformers, the oldest of which is a free flash game from 2004. The ninja you play as (which looks to be made out of punctuation marks in the new art style), can jump, walljump, and has a round hitbox that carries weight and preserves its momentum. The levels, albeit made from a level builder, test your ability to manipulate the physics in some in some surprising and intimate ways. 

All hazards in the game either follow a set path or are reactive to your movements, giving N++ the tone of a digital sort of Pinball game, or a platformer's answer to Sudoku. These levels are packed in chunks of 4, with collectibles adding to your death timer, which is preserved. Often, these sets will start with a few easy levels with optional paths that can net you some extra time for the longer, time consuming levels at the end of the set. The only thing that bothers me about this 4-level structure is that it's the one tool they don't give to players posting their levels online. In user-created levels, the entire structure of the experience needs to fit in a single room.

An absolutely outstanding execution of a simple premise. The game is great for any level of interest and even without the community created levels has more than enough to keep you entertained for hours.

It's still got the sleek aesthetics and fluid momentum based movement of its predecessor N+, even including all of the original levels from that game. It's really just more of the same, and while usually I would say this game doesn't add enough to stand on its own, the fact N+ isn't available on PC makes this a no brainer. The level editor is extremely simple and intuitive yet powerful, and allows for some super creative user made levels.

However, no online multiplayer is a massive disappointment. Even if it was laggy and bug infested like N+ it would be infinitely better than just omitting it.

Its like every other N game! Its fun at first, then you reach a point where it gets to hard and it no longer fun! Why play a game that feels like a chore? Games are supposed to be time-wasting fun! Not frustrating and almost impossible torture devices!

Edit: I get the purpose of difficult games, but by telling somone to "Get Gud" or saying "Quit crying noob" doesn't change one's oppinion. I could find an easy as shit game and play the fuck out of that (Like I did this), and still say the game was shite. The difficulty doesn't make a game good or bad, but if the difficulty draws a player away, regardless of its difficulty, if it doesn't captive and interest a player, than that player should be obligated to determine wather or not that game was decent or not, and in this case, was it terrible? Absolutly not, it's a flawed game, I'm comparing its factor of price, total fun, and the desire to come back and play it again. This game, fails in the "Returning" factor. I've played Binding of Isaac, I've played Dark Soul's, now, the thing with Binding of Isaac, allthough, hard, it gets very enjoyable, and is very fun regardless. This game, is not. Now, I know Binding of Isaac has a very different game mechanic, but if you want to say "Get Good." Fine, but did you enjoy it? If yes, fine! If no, Fine! All I'm saying is I have never found the desire to play this game after a troubling session. And for another example, Slime Rancher, easy as shit, but after you hit a point of maximumiazation, you're done, and you have no desire to play after that, or start over! That's all I'm saying! So, frankly, saying "get good" is not going to disvalue my argument. Now "achievment." Sure, you feel fucking great once in a while don't you? But, there's a point where that satisfaction is lost, and you no longer enjoy victory. Going back to the easy games, even if you're a god, you get bored wrecking scrubs all day don't you? What I'm saying is, a good game is a perfect balnce of reward, skill, and other content. This game, requires a lot of  skill, fine. Reward? You get some skins.. some more levels... some more backrounds.... You don't get anything new, and content, sure there's a lot of levels, but when I mean content, I mean diverse content, content that is different. Multiuplayer: Local. Meh, its not that great of a game. Simply put it. If you think saying a game is bad because its not fun, Say its not fun. Even if that game is "For hardcore gamers", You have the right as a consumer to state your oppinion, obviously, you should get pretty far in the game (Which I did) To get a general taste. So, in conlusion, just because some one say's "get gud" doesn't make your oppinion any less valuable than others. AND THAT WHY ITS CALLED A REVIEW! I'M GIVING MY OPPINION ON A TOPIC! JUST BECAUSE YOU LIKE THIS GAME DOESN'T MAKE YOU A BAD PERSON! If anything, it makes you look childish, and unwilling to listen to others if if they might have vulauble points and critisisms. So, if a games bad, say something. Which I have.

I bought N++ the day it was released. As a fan of the series, I greatly enjoyed the new content, as I imagine most fans would. However, I was disappointed at how buggy the game was on release, so I wrote a negative review explaining the problems that existed. I received a reply from the developers explaining that many of those problems would be fixed in upcoming patches and the Ultimate Edition update. I removed my review and waited.

Yesterday I reinstalled N++ more than a year after the Ultimate Edition update was released. Once again I am disappointed that three major problems with leaderboards still exist:

1. The leaderboards on several episodes have been hacked. At least one of them was hacked sometime around January 2017, and it still has not been fixed.

2. Leaderboards do not consistently display player names correctly. Special characters do not work, and there is a fixed limit to how many characters a single leaderboard can display. This results in player names being truncated, or in some cases, left off entirely. 

3. The overall leaderboard has still not been implemented. On /r/nplusplus one of the developers claimed "We definitely intend on adding this" and "this is near the top [of the priority list], after bugs." That was in September 2016. 

I will gladly switch my review to positive if the developers fix the obvious issues and implement the feature they have been promising since the game launched.

Back in 2005, the original [i]N[/i] was released. It was both great time killer and great platformer with simple mechanics. In 2016, [i]N++[/i] is unleashed on PC - bigger and better.
[b][i]Mini review just for the sake of it.[/i][/b]

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Everything is simple as 95% of platformers go: you don't have any specific skills, you can run, jump, wall-jump and that's basically it. Everything depends on HOW you do it and whether you keep your momentum. Enemies range from simple mines to not so simple rocket and lazer shooting [i]turrets[/i].
In order to progress, you start an episode and finish every level by activating the exit and reaching it within time limit. Rules slightly change between available in-game modes, which include:
[list]
[*][b]Solo.[/b] Finish an episode with 5 levels before you die. Initially, you have 90 seconds, but that time can be increased by collecting gold (each piece adds 2 seconds). It's not necessary and often dangerous, but also improves your chances if you take a slow cautious aproach. Dying reset the timer to a value that you had at the start of the level allowing to retry over and over until you successed.
[*][b]Hardcore.[/b] Mode uses the same episodes as [b]Solo[/b], but now instead of 5 levels there are 25 and everytime you die, the timer isn't reset (there are now no infinite retries of the level), and collected gold is added to the timer only once the level is complete.
[*][b]Co-op.[/b] Same as [b]Solo[/b], except now there up to 4 players and only 1 has to reach the exit. Levels may be straight forward with both players moving in the same direction or can be divided into several isolated segments.
[*][b]Race.[/b] Up to 4 players race to the exit to gain scores, the first one to reach the maximum wins.
[/list]
The first 2 modes can also be played in co-op, but are not designed to.
There are more than 300+ episodes in [b]Solo[/b] alone, in addition to other modes, community workshop, and unlockable secret challenges.
Overall, gameplay is addictive and easy to get, but certain "tricks" can be hard to master and certain levels are rage inducing (just like in the old times).

[h1]Sound[/h1]
The original had only sound effects for enemies, ninja and menu. This time around we've got a range of tracks to spice things up: there's ambient, there's dub, there's minimal techno and whatnot. 50+ tracks is enought to fill the vacuum without getting old.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Graphics are clear, minimalistic with minimal fluff to clutter the screen.
But apart from that, the game has color customization, which is both good and bad thing. Some palettes are good, some are headache inducing and hard to read. It seems that some were added just for the sake of adding more content.
There's also character customization but that's something entirely unnecessary: changes are barely noticable.
Overall, the right tools are given and for the player to get what is going on the screen without burning ones eyes.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
Simplistic, minimalistic, addictive, packed with enough content to play for 30+ hours, [i]N++[/i] is a steal even at full price if you're up for some no BS classic platformer. It may get old or frustrating at times, but that is why you always can take a break and get back later without need to remember the mechanics, the plot or where you left off: just launch, open level select screen and jump right back at it.

For those that don't know, 'N' has been around since around 2003/2004 and over the years has gone through several versions on different platforms. For those interested in the games history the exact details and older versions themselves can be found on their website.

I started playing 'N 1.4' in early 2008 and became addicted, after a thousand or so hours on that title I moved on to the newer version, 'N 2.0'.

I've been playing the game on and off over the years, sometimes going 6 months+ without playing yet the game has always been on my computer for the last decade and bit by bit I've accumulated a fair amount of time. So, after so much time spent playing such a great game I was a little apprehensive about this new version. Would it live up to the legacy of the older ones I fell in love with?

In a word: Yes!

Imo it strikes a great balance between staying true to the original game and giving us something new and justifying a new game. Not only does it deliver some great new content but the game now being fullscreen and released for modern computers makes it run amazingly smooth. The increased functionality in N++ gives the game something I wasn't even aware it needed.

In conclusion, if you love older versions of N or are someone looking to try something new, give N++ a go. The gameplay itself and almost unlimted replayability of the game more than justifies the money, when you throw in the amazing soundtrack, additional user generated content and overall ambiance and asthetics the game delivers then it's really a no brainer.

N++ is absolutely not for everyone, it's a deceptively simple looking platforming game, that can be brutally difficult. The sheer amount of levels (4340) makes it already well worth it's price, although you should prepare yourself for trail and error. The levels of various degrees of difficulties is accompanied by a wonderful electronic soundtrack with about 6 hours of music (which is great, truly wonderful soundtrack to play to). Although, personally, after playing it for 6 hours, it kind of gets tiring to me to trail and error myself through every level. Luckily the various different color schemes keep the game interesting and somewhat fresh. Also a word of warning: Controller is almost neccesary on the later, more difficult levels.

Get this game if you like platforming and don't mind dying a lot (although to some sweet electronic music so that helps). As for the price, I'd get it regardless if it is on sale or not, this game is well worth it's pricetag.

My absolute favorite platformer. The feeling of skill mastery is very amplified in this game as death, while frustrating, only keeps you from your next run for all of a quarter second. Perfect controls and physics, it'll never leave you with the sense that a death was unfair.

WOW!  As someone who used to (notice past tense) mostly play story heavy or open-world RPGs or strategy games, I was very surprised with how much I liked N++.  Lately, I've had less time to delve deeply into a story-rich game, and games like this that I can pick up/put down whenever are my go to.

If you love platformers, puzzlers, or even racing games (there is a timing element to each level), you will very likely LOVE N++!  No matter your skill level, you WILL get better if you persist.  And, unless you get obsessed (easy to do..."just one more try...!), it's always fun.  It's great for developing mental focus and spatial problem-solving perseverance, as many of the later levels are so deviously designed that the slightest difference in speed, motion, or timing can make all the difference between making it through or being blown to bits...over...and over...and over again.  I have attempted some levels hundreds of time and have yet to beat them.  Yeah, I'm not the best, but I do it for fun and to blow off steam.

The retro aesthetics of the game, including the awesome electro/trance soundtrack, make the experience that much more addicting:  many fun color schemes to choose from.  I would describe it as a very "zen" gaming experience.  If you let yourself tense up (and you will!), your performance will suffer.  Breathe and focus.  Calmly analyze each scenario where you went wrong.  N++ rewards cool and collected problem solving...but you still have to apply it on a dime!  Some of the levels are downright sadistic, with little to no room for any errors.  I've heard some people describe this game as "the 'Dark Souls' of platformers."  There is some merit to that.  I just reached over 5000 deaths today (yes, they have achievements for how many times you die...that's how much you WILL die in this game lol).

Bottom line:  highly enjoyable retro-styled platformer with deviously clever and difficult levels.  Low system reqs for those without uber gaming rigs.  N++ will fire your brain up, raise your heart rate, and make you sweat!  Warning:  if acute motor skills are difficult or frustrating for you, you might find yourself very frustrated with this game, as it requires a verrrry twitchy/delicate sense of control.  Not recommended for late night playing, unless you don't mind not sleeping.  Whether it's for 15 minutes or 3 hours, N++ is a good time!

I spent hours and hours back in the day playing N, the free Flash game that preceded N+ and N++.  For that alone I would have passed some money the developer's way, but N++ is definitely worth it by itself.  It's a tough, unforgiving platformer in the mould of Super Meat Boy (or vice versa, given how old N is).  It has a peculiar momentum-based approach to platformer (screw physics!).  Once you get the hang of it, you'll be performing incredible walljumps and near-flying around levels.  There's a huge amount of levels to play; 9 hours in and I've barely completed half of them.

If I have one complaint, it's the adjustment in approach from N.  In N and N++ you have gold which you can collect to extend your forever-reducing timer.  In N, you had to go out of your way to collect gold to give yourself enough time to complete episodes (sets of 5 levels).  The only question was on which level you were going to divert to make sure you had enough time for later levels.  In N++, you can complete every episode (that I've played so far -- including several in E, the toughest category) without worrying about the timer.  You collect lots of gold easily on your way round, and you never have to worry about the time.  The gold is just if you want to get a high-score.  I can understand that this is a new approach: always completable but you can go back for high scores, but it means an episode is just an independent set of 5 levels. I miss the tension that the timer added in N.

Still, recommended if you like games that kill you brutally every 2.3 seconds, but after one button press you're up and running again.  This time, you can avoid that mine. This time, you can jump over the missile.  This time, you got killed by a machine gun. But next time, next time was the mine. Then past the mine, but killed by the missile. Then the mine again. Then the machine gun once more.  Next time though, next time...

I was a huge original N fan. I've been playing N since before N+ for XBLA came out. I enjoyed making maps, jumping around, and having my hopes and dreams crused by 88-4 in N 1.4.

N++ is a game I would unreservedly recommend for anyone who was a fan of the original N, or for someone who enjoys physics-based platformers and challenge. It stays very true to the original N while adding some new mechanics that give a fresh new twist to the game (current favorite mechanic: toggle mines).

Its performance is a huge improvement over the original N in ways that actually matter. Corner jumps can be done very reliably now for those with the skill to do them, and laser drones in pits will fire at you the exact moment you come into sight.

Have I mentioned that I really like the levels? The intro section is a fantastic overview of the basics, which means the main game is free to get right into the meat of the gameplay without too much faffing about. All the levels in the N++ section are new, where the legacy episodes are derived from old levels that have been cleaned up and tweaked for N++.

I do have a few minor gripes, however. Make no mistake, though, these are minor.

* Sometimes, N++ feels a little TOO faithful to the original N. Death by falling from too high on a bounceblock is still a thing, as is the strange frictional interaction on the top surfaces of horizontally-moving thwumps. I can only assume these are still here for historical reasons, since it otherwise makes no sense (though I have hunches as to why they are the way they are within the code).
* I know that collecting all the gold is an optional objective, but some levels make collecting all the gold a time consuming but not altogether challenging process, with individual flecks widely spaced out but numerous.
* The death replay in the main menu includes suicides, which ends up showing a lot of replays where I suicided due to not being happy with my time or getting one piece of gold that I would still have an opportunity to get later. Preferably, the death replays would only show suicides when the topology of the map changed such that the exit became permanently inaccessible, but that gets a touch complicated.
* N++'s tiles don't seem to include several "micro" tiles that I believe were present in N+ XBLA. I would have loved to see those make a comeback and for there to be more of them.
* I haven't found a built-in way to import old N levels into N++. That would have been nice.
* There are some audio and UI bugs, but I'll leave those out of this review. I have some faith they'll get patched eventually.

EDIT: I made a comment about off-putting keybindings in this review. Since that has been changed, my complaint has been removed. This game is awesome.
Buy a backup controller.

Over my entire life as a gamer, N in it's various incarnations is my most played game by a LONG, LONG shot. Some amazing games are 10-hour experiences, 20 if you replay and look for everything. This is the game built to last a lifetime. It does this by a number of vectors: 

1) a ridiculously high skill celing with open ended parkour-style gameplay which means that already open-ended levels offer an almost infinite continuum of routes, shortcuts and stunts you can pull off (despite being a three button game). Good games show off how creative the level and game designers are; timeless games let the player show off their own creativity in gameplay.

2) A TON of levels, thousands of them, multiple goals and playstyles (all gold, highscore, speedrunning, local multiplayer, lots of secret missions and unlockables) and that all important level editor with online sharing and leaderboards. This, combined with an extremely rich and finetuned movement and gameplay design means the game literally never ends. You can always get better, you can always play new levels, and you can always make new levels.

3) The online leaderboards which I mentioned before mean you can always get better at any level, and doing so gives you tangible rewards - replays that you can watch and of course that sweet, sweet highscore on the leaderboard. This drives the community to push the envelope with regards to creative routing through the level and to find ever more ways to speed the ninja up.

4) The aforementioned finely-tuned gameplay. There are lots of platform games around, but none of them have the unique feel of N, and by extension, N++. Use your momentum to fling yourself around the screen, over huge chasms, around loops, up mountains and down into deadly caverns. Walljumping off of slopes, curves and (of course) walls, plus the interactions with level geometry and objects creates an endless variety of tricks to invent, discover and master.

Imagine the visceral thrill and speed of Sonic, the constant forward-planning and puzzle platforming of Lode Runner, and the challenge of Meat Boy only much more scalable due to you being able to set your own goals in the game. No other game can make me wince, scream, uncontrollably jump out of my seat or curse the level designer and call them horrible things like N++. No other game has a movement physics so precise that you can almost feel your character touching the walls and grazing past deadly mines.

With no scrolling, no fancy graphics or decorations, no storyline and no real mystery, each level gives you a god's-eye view of every trap, every enemy and every platform. Planning forwards becomes essential to weave in and out of enemies, what seems impossible eventually becomes second nature. You will level up as a player, not a character; and you will learn to cope with extreme stress and continue to press on against an overwhelming feeling of hopelessness.

Finally, the presentation is a perfect melding of form and function, inspired by minimalist art, op art, technical diagrams, floor plans of buildings and architecture in general, the vector graphics and contemporary colour schemes are complimented by the smoothest framerate and literally perfect controls. Polish drips off of the game like one of those glossy magazines.

One of the timeless games, and the best skill-based platformer ever devised, taking the art of platforming down to the level of a sport and, dare I say it, a passion.

It allows both for easily performing cool acrobatics and for some extremely difficult advanced manouvers, and makes speedrunning a blast. And turning a fatal fall into a speed boost by landing on a slope just feels right.

There's lots of neat palletes to unlock, a fully functional level editor, and a huge number of well-designed official levels in the campaign. What more can you ask for?

The only flaw, which is irredeemably a big one if you enjoyed it in N+, is the lack of online multiplayer. there are several options for local games, but when there is so much content, infinite levels and such well inbuilt coop options, it seems lacking for there to not be online multiplayer of any kind. The devs have made the reason clear why this is the case, and it doesn't seem like it will ever come, but here's hoping.

All in all N++ is an almost perfect example of how a game can be true to it's roots but also succeed them. Just like the Witcher 3 is to the Witcher 2, N++ is an almost flawless sequel.

N++ is one hell of an hardcore game, but a freaking good one. Tons of fun, tons of content, tons of homicidal robots, no lives, up to four ninjas. It can be frustrating at times, but you'll never feel like you died in an unfair way. 

The gameplay is mostly focused on an extremely polished jumping system that takes into account momentum, speed and angles, making the game pretty hard to handle for the first time, even harder to master, but really satisfying once you are able to pull out your parkour skills. Your goal ? Unlock the exit and get out of here with as much gold as possible.

The game have also two multiplayer modes : the first one is a competitive race mode while the other one is a cooperation mode. The game also gives you a level editor to  make and share your levels all around the world. You can also play other people's levels, on PC as well as on PS4.

There's a couple of bad points though : first, no online mode. If you want to play multiplayer it'll be on the same PC, likely with up to four people sharing the same keyboard. It's okay when you're just two but when you're four it can become a bit messy. Another issue is that the game can become a bit repetitive : most of what you'll do is jumping around after all.

Anyway, N++ is definitely a game I would advise you to buy, especially if you're a fan of hardcore platformers like Super Meat Boy. It's excellent gameplay, great level design and incredble replay value makes N++ one of the best PC games of 2016.

This game is Pac-Man as a platformer, and I mean this in the grandest of all possible senses. 

N++'s timelessness is unmatched by any other game in its genre. If you think Celeste is "precise", Super Meat Boy is "hard", Super Mario is "expressive", you're not wrong — but, still, N++ distills all of these qualities in the purest, most refined experience of jumping and moving in a 2D space.  

Unbound by any concern whatsoever with things like narrative, worldbuilding, or thematic cohesion, N++ is just lines. Each of its *checks wikipedia* four thousand three hundred and forty stages (!!) is made up of a few perfectly straight lines, a mere dozen or so types of enemies and traps, and a number of square "coins" you may pick up as you traverse the level if you have the gall to go for any score higher than "I was able to clear this level somehow". 

The only two things that prop up this ridiculous game are pure, unadulterated level design intelligence, and a physics engine that would make Einstein himself soil his trousers. Every single input you give to this game works double or triple duty. You know how in Super Smash Bros you can control the height of your jump depending on how long you press the button, and you can also do a "short hop" by lightly tapping it with a level of subtlety that's frankly unbecoming of the fighting genre? That is good gameplay. Now, imagine that, but better. Bonkers better. Infinite levels of either floatiness or short-hoppy-ness at the tip of your finger, dictated only by your eagerness and/or patience to let go of the A button. 

If the Ninja you control in N++ could leave traces of paint in the screen, we would most certainly have N++ artists, such is the expressiveness and gracefulness of this character, in these levels, with these physics, in this game. 

(I'll have more to say, but I'll publish this now because I have other pressing matters. It will suffice as a review for now.)

N++ is an awesome physics driven platformer with an insane amount of levels. The levels are divided into five level clusters to make things digestible. Very easy to hop in and out of this game.

You are a "ninja" who seeks gold. You have a limited amount of time to beat each cluster of levels. Collecting gold adds time to your time limit. The goal is to complete each level cluster with the most amount of time possible. It's possible to complete most clusters by ignoring gold and making a b-line to the end, however collecting gold takes you on a dangerous course that increases your score. The risk reward factor is real. 

The small "sprites?" "vector graphics?" scale incredibly on a 4k display. The art style is simple but sharp. The animations are silky smooth. Dying sends your character into a dramatic funny ragdoll, that often bounces off of enemies, and blows up into physic driven pieces from bombs. 

The gameplay is just great. This is a PURE single screen platformer.  All you do is run, jump, wall jump, and dodge. Every move and ricochet increases your speed which helps or hampers your efforts. You analyze the screen and dive right in. There's a great variety of enemies and traps to keep you on your toes. The level design is fantastic and plentiful. Even though the jump physics are a bit floaty, the screen real estate is HUGE and the direct control of your character is sharp. It feels great.

The coop modes and online score tracker just add to the experience.  

This is the best PURE platforming experience ever! You don't need power ups. I've never felt like such a savage just jumping and dodging before. The pick up and play aspect keeps this game in my rotation constantly. Just watch a few videos and you'll know if this one is for you. You can always try the original flash game, as it's basically the same game, different levels.

These games are just GREAT!

A limitless platformer with endless content and a whole lotta depth. There's much more to N++ than what appears on the surface. My favorite "hardcore" platformer since Dustforce. One thing I will hate on, however, are the hitboxes. There's an invisible area around the player character that will set off mines, etc.

There's nothing to say other than this is a perfect platformer. The controls are intuitive and responsive, and the level design is consistently great throughout the hundreds of levels. If you have any interest in platformers, you should absolutely get this game.

Before we start, fair warning I feel like this rn https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3KquFZYi6L0

I love the game, and I have 500+ hours on both Xbox and PC, along with maybe 10 hours on Switch. The game's mechanics are simple and overall make for a good fun experience.
Let me get to the point here:
Most people who don't play too much (maybe 50-100 hours) will say the N++ tab A-C row is fine, but after that it's too much. Of course, I have spent enough time to say Ultimate edition D row onwards (D-E and "extra content"/spoilers) is where it gets too hard, and the difficulty curve is insanely steep at that point. I beat Ult E today, and the last level took me an hour and a half, and that's not the longest I've spent on a level before. Here's the worst part: it gets even worse. I have seen the best players throw in over 5000 attempts at a few levels for (spoiler) reasons. Notably: Eeny-Meeny-Mine-y Moan, Compendium For Literates, Blood Monkey, The Catch, and a few others. The game definitely holds up to it's marketing, by far too much. The game gets much too difficult for anyone's good, and it's best to play casually unless you want to spend 1000s of hours improving and getting frustrated. 100% has been achieved by less than 20 people and the game has a high skilled community, with people playing the same mechanics and improving for 15 years since the original N.

Now that I have that over with, here's my review on the rest of the game: Highscoring in general is super fun and movement flows perfectly. I love mapping, and it's really fun to find new ways to set up specific tiles/entities and see what you can do, each map (hopefully) being unique and very versatile while still being extremely approachable. Most importantly, the community for the game is the best part, we hang out in the discord (join us too at http://discord.gg/nplusplus) and chat about highscores, community projects (like a tab), mapping, and completion, and sometimes vent in channels and ask for support (literally in game, and figuratively while playing lol). I recently have begun to speedrun this game, and that is super fun especially on earlier rows, my personal favorite is B row.

Overall great game, smooth gameplay and tons of content, levels, and opportunity, but much too hard, I would suggest playing casually and not really thinking about 100%. I am not saying don't do completion, just it gets hard to the point of pixel perfect or frame perfect jumps and that's not fun.

I love this game, and I think if you enjoy platformers it's a disservice to yourself not to give this game a shot. One of the best co-op and single player games I've ever played. 

N++ is tough, real tough; but also easy, real easy. The range of emotions you'll feel while playing this game ranges from downright painful to a euphoric high from finally completing a level you've been stuck on for hours. Some levels are easy levels that give you a break - some easy wins to get you feeling good. Other levels are painfully hard and test you and your friend's patience with both the game and each other. I've played this game in single player, and in multiplayer with different amounts of people and different combinations of skill levels. 

It's amazing how many different experiences you can have with this game by simply changing the amount of people you're playing with. A co-op level that was simple with 3-4 people is now a brain teasing puzzle with 2. Single player levels can be a fun romp with 2 people, but can be ball bustingly hard by yourself. The game is highly customizable in a sense depending on how many friends with a high difficulty tolerance you've got. 

I'm honestly not sure how to describe the level design because it changes based on how you're approaching the levels. If you want to collect all the coins in a level it's going to often times be much harder than if you just run through the level disregarding the coins. Levels can range from a well crafted challenge to an easy speedrun based on your priorities alone. There are also [spoiler]secret challenges you can unlock that make you do specific tasks in each level[/spoiler], although I haven't unlocked any of them yet and didn't know about them until I looked up how to unlock some extra stuff online. The game has over 4000 levels, so there's a few that feel like stinkers in there, but the majority of the 4000+ levels are fun - which is incredibly impressive. 

I highly recommend N++ if you like challenging platformers. I've played it for over 20 hours and I still haven't gotten through a third of the levels. It's fun with friends and fun alone. Honestly near perfect in terms of what I want from a platformer like this.

N++ stands out as one of (if not _the_ best) platformers of all time. With practice and a mere 3 buttons for in-game inputs (left, right, and jump), one can try to attain complete mastery and control over the ninja. There does not (and will never) exist a player who will have perfect control, as that is a peak we can only strive for. This game makes the journey towards that peak a joy, regardless of how far you want to take it.

With minimalistic graphics composed of clean lines and filled-in geometric shapes, and a joking spoof of a story, this is a game entirely focused on gameplay and the player experience within its levels. And in this area, it does better than any other game ever has.

I think that problems with this game are caused by minimalistic controls. You control the ninja only with 3 keys - left, right and jump. Movement still requires skill because it is momentum based, so the ninja takes lots of time to accelerate. The control of this momentum becomes a second nature after a while and it feels good to make some tricky manuver and retain your speed. Unfortunately there are also enemies. You will have to dodge those rockets and jump between fast moving enemy-dots. This theoretically makes it so that planning and subconscious anticipation of enemy moves is essential and your fast reflexes won't save you. Unfortunately in practice you still need to have quick reflexes and timing, but you have to make you split second decision a second before the danger really happens. For instance there was this flustrating level where you have to jump between fast moving dots. You cannot start your run and jump just before there is an opening, you have to start it some time earlier. It felt like quick reacting to non-existant signal.

I also don't really like the level design. In many platformers when you are going with the intended speed then to some extent timing of environment and enemies synchronizes to give you satisfying feeling and to tell you that you are doing it right. It doesn't happen here. There are many roads you can take when solving level and due to enemies reacting to your presence situation quite quickly becomes random (there is no rng in this game, but your interaction with environment still may led to dangerous unforeseen situations). Someone may even enjoy the self dependence required to tackle such situations, but I would rather have more manufactured experience where everything that happens was planned by developers. Each level has achievement for collecting all gold (which lets you unlock even more levels). Oftentimes there is a lot of gold scattered around the level and collecting it all requires a long, complicated and messy route and constant dealing with quickly changing enemy situation.

Not all issues appear in all levels. You have to finish 5 levels to unlock them. In those 5 levels some will be easy, some will be quite enjoyable, but there may appear some really flustrating one. If you decide to quit you will have to start unlocking this set of 5 episodes from the beginning next time. This is especially flustrating if in your opinion this level should be removed from the game. Probably when there are so many levels bad ones are bound do happen.
