Easily the best platformer I've played. It takes a lot of time and refinement to make a game system that is basically perfect, and this is one of ~3 game's I've seen do it. 

Pros:
- Perfectly fair: Shows you all level layouts and enemy patterns from the beginning of the game, so there are no surprises. 
- Great control: Control feels extremely natural and provides adequate player expression in the game space.
- Satisfying gameplay: Tension and release cycles are wound into multiple systems, meaning gameplay is always fun. (IE 
            speed is hard to build up but rewarding to have; getting more gold is good but often puts you in more danger)
- Overwhelming amount of content: Has over 2000 levels and a level editor, so you will inevitably be done with the game
            before the game runs dry of content. This lets you consume the exact amount of gameplay you want.
- Great music, and lets you add your own music if you don't like the default
- Full leaderboards with frame and pixel-perfect records
- Online level sharing
- Local multiplayer: Not many games let me have 4 people crowded around my PC anymore

Cons:
- Not perfectly optimised for all resolutions
- No online multiplayer (I know this was avoided due to ping messing with replay recording, but they could have still tried)
- I died over 400 times on one level

Very disappointed. I've never had to refund a game for it not working. The graphic settings do not work on my computer, tried every single resolution with fullscreen on/off, and the game just doesn't render correctly, I can only see the bottom right corner of the game, as if the window isnt centered correctly on my screen. I played N+ back on the Xbox 360 and loved it, so when I saw this game, I was excited.

Easy to learn, hard to master. Literally every millisecond matters in this game. oh you pressed the jump key too long? too bad you just died. you jumped too soft? dead. You have to be precise. It's really fun to play it once in a while. I wouldn't recommend playing it all day because it'd be bad for your sanity since levels get exponentially harder. I usually play it 1-2 hours a day. But that FEELING when you beat a level is.. simply wonderful. Totally worth it after dying 600 times on the same bloody level. No sarcasm. And there are soooo many levels;

Solo: 1625 levels
Co-op: 800 levels
Race: 1000 levels (this mode especially is ton of fun and totally recommended if you wanna start a blood feud with your siblings)

Total number of 3425 levels you have to beat. I didn't include the 1625 levels of hardcore because it's the same levels as solo but only this time you need to be faster. Much faster.

There was ''only'' 500 levels in the first N game that came out in 2005. So this is a huge improvement. There's more variety in this too. Many different enemies. Different game modes. Better graphics. Fullscreen. And AMAZING soundtracks.

It deserves to be bought at full price. It's not expensive, there's no dlcs, no micro-transactions, no early access and all that bs like everywhere else. Simply a great game. In my opinion the best platformer game ever made.

Edit: After completing the first block of 500 N++ levels, I saw another 100 levels appear! the X row. That means other blocks of levels have the same additional hidden 100 levels that appear once you complete the block. Which means theres definitely 4000+ levels in total.

Lovely isn't it

Edit 2: I see now in the description it says already that there are 4340 levels in total :P Anyway I hope this review was helpful to you, thanks for reading and have fun

N++ is probably the best platformer ever made.
The physics are very well-tuned, and feel fair and interesting even after hundreds of hours of gameplay
The visuals are slick, understandable, and complement the minimalist design of the game.
The music also acts as very nice background noise to the game and can be listened to for a very long time while zoning out to the game.

But, the biggest selling point of the game is its level design. The game has thousands of levels, ranging from easy to almost impossible, and somehow, a supermajority of them are good (with each player probably disliking a few due to their preferences). They cause the game to be a constant stream of learning and improvement, until eventually you can do what previously took hours, in a matter of just a few attempts. They feature many different aspects: Routing, precision, improvisation, speed. The levels take the features of the game to their extremes, the game leaves no stone unturned, leading the final levels to be some of the most interesting levels i've ever played.

Overall, it's a fantastic experience if you have any interest in platformers.

[h1]Putting the 'N' in 'FUN';  You'll add the 'F-U'.[/h1]

N++ is a platformer built around very simple concepts - Running, jumping, getting to the exit by any means possible, and dying.  Loads and loads of dying.

[h3]STORY, I GUESS?[/h3]

There's an excuse of a story.  You're a ninja, seeking enlightenment through 5-room challenges known as 'Episodes'.  Your superhuman metabolism can only be sustained with the delight of gold, and if time runs out, you die.  [b]That's it.[/b]

[h3]GAMEPLAY[/h3]

Indeed, N++ is all about the gameplay.  Your goal's to first hit an exit switch, then make for the door, while not getting killed or running out of time.  This simple goal is made fiendishly difficult for three reasons.  First, you cannot take any damage, otherwise you die, with your ragdoll typically getting abused in ways that loop from horrifying to hilarious.  Half the fun sometimes is just watching how your dead body gets abused this time.

Second problem?  Everything that isn't terrain, a switch, a door, or you, wants to kill you.  Gauss gun drones, mines, copies of yourself that follow after you, drones that orbit paths, drones that zero in on you, mines, falling too fast, ascending too fast, the timer, mines, and laser drones all want you as dead as possible, and all will kill you if you miscalculate even once.

Third issue?  You're on a 90-second time limit, and every bit of gold adds a paltry 2 seconds to that clock.  What's more, gold is often placed in precarious positions, and you'll often need to extend the timer out to make it through an episode, forcing you to put yourself at greater risk.

This is a very simple game on the surface, with clearly defined mechanics, and it also manages to be insanely, excruciatingly hard, without being outright unfair.  This isn't quite a rage game, though it does come damn close to being one.  Everything is quickly communicated, restarting is easy, you have unlimited lives, and the game keeps it's levels confined to one screen's worth of space.  The difficulty comes in navigating these short levels without getting zapped, shot, exploded, crushed, or slamming into the floors too hard, all while keeping within the time limit.  It's extremely easy to get into N++, and extremely difficult to master it.

There's multiplayer, too!  Co-op or competitive, as well as a level editor and sharing included, letting you play whatever fiendish deathtraps the community has cooked up and will cook up until the heat death of the universe.  Haven't played it, but I know it exists, and that the community has likely encouraged others to 'git N-lightened'.

[h3]GRAPHICS[/h3]

Graphics are like the story; minimalist, to this game's benefit and to my delight.  N's style was always sort of minimalist - The biggest effects typically relegated to your demise, after all - And all the better for it, and N++ keeps this minimalism and cranks it up a notch or two, with your ninja barely any better than a stick figure here, but still conveying their current state of being perfectly.  Enemies are little better - Anything aside from communicating to you exactly what they are and how they plan on killing you has been excised.  All of this sounds like it shouldn't work, and yet everything remains utterly readable.  It helps that everything is typically confined to a single screen's worth of real estate.  No losing yourself, nothing that isn't contributing to gameplay in some way, shape, or form.  Pure minimalistic perfectioN.

[h3]REPLAY VALUE + IS IT WORTH IT?[/h3]

Replayability is a major factor of N++ - Improving your times, going for no-death runs, trying new levels, or simply going through your favorites is quite easy, and the game's clearly built to be enjoyed for quite some time.

Is N++ worth the money?  That depends.  This game is definitely not for everyone, mind you.  It can be FRUSTRATING.  It's difficult.  It's never unfair, it's never impossible, and everything is clearly communicated to you, but N++ can be a maddeningly difficult game due to level design and enemy placement being very tight indeed.

If you're into that sort of thing, N++ is worth the dough.  If you're the type to frustrate easily, best look elsewhere.

About as dead simple as a platformer can get. Movement and jumping controls and feels excellent, which is perhaps the single most important thing a platformer can get right. Level design is great as well, and there certainly isn't a shortage of them.

As pure as is possible for a platforming game to be. No weird movement tech, no extraneous crap, just a good base concept, two movement keys, a jump button, and a physics engine.

N++ is a whole lotta fun. Nastily difficult Flash-era platforming, with a lot of nice looks and neat song choices to accompany the game's nice variety of levels made by Metanet themselves? Neat combo.

There will be a grind to unlock a myriad of different colour schemes, though, but the one I recommend the most is the Classic one, unlocked by completing your first column of Legacy levels. You can also use Vasquez if you haven't unlocked anything.

I feel it's worth the £11 asking price, but do not trust what I say about this game's worth for its cost as some of the levels will get annoying later on. Make your own judgement. I will say though, this game rightfully deserves its "Overwhelmingly Positive" score.

There is also a level editor and fan-made level catalog where you can play other peoples' levels, so have all the fun you can with that alongside Metanet's levels.

Oh, and if you play on Steam Deck, you can get away with 60fps on a 3w TDP limit! So much battery life!

Absolutely incredible.  N++ harkens back to a time when games were simply games.  There's no cinematics here, no flashy graphics and no convoluted skill trees and unlocks.  Some may find that to be a negative.  To me, unless I'm playing a RPG, I don't want story.  Simplistic graphics are elegant and take away all confusion which leaves you with nothing but your skill standing between you and the goal.  Which brings me to my last point.  There's no unlocks or upgrades here to help you compensate for your lack of skill or experience with the game.  If you want to "git gud" at this game, then you will have to play it and actively improve your platforming abilities.  

Factor in many levels and the ability to create and share your own and you have an incredible value for the money.  Platforming fans, it's [redacted] Christmas!

I played this game for over 60 hours on PS4, getting every achievement (currently the same achievements on both platforms).  

**Skip this first paragraph if you want to get straight to pros, cons, and opinion**
     N++ is a simple in concept minimalistic 2d platformer.  Guide your character, the ninja, avoiding various traps, obstactles, and fall damage in search of riches. (gold coins scattered throughout levels).  The ninja can wall jump and move in any direction.  Every level has at least one door switch that opens a door to the end of the level.  Navigate to that open door to finish a level.  There are between 2000 and 2500 total official levels in three modes called Co-op, race, and solo mode ranging from easy/tutorial scaling up to the extremely challenging.  All of these modes consist of episodes that have a pack of 5 levels together.  As time passes in a level the score counts down.  When that score hits 0 the ninja explodes and must start the level over.  The time is additive in every episode.  Collecting gold adds time.  After beating an episode, it is possible to select levels individually.  There are global leaderboards for every individual level and episode as well as friend leaderboards and replays for every best personal score.  There is an in-game editor where players can make and play community made levels.    

Pros:
-Fantastic control of character.  Seemingly limitless possibilities with different routes and strategies.
-Enough game content to play for well over 100 hours.
-Game content is all extremely high quality.  This game just keeps giving unexpectedly, even more than advertised.  The developers were perfectionists with this game arguably to a fault from a game developer's perspective.  A fantastic opportunity for the consumer.  It is obviously a game made out of love over a long period of time.
-Devs plan to add even more content (more levels and game modes) and always intently listen to their player base. 
-Soundtrack is 3+ hours of high quality music.
-Players have full access to a level editor where we can make and play user levels that also have leaderboards.
-Game scales in difficulty appropriately so that it is newbie friendly and then turns into an expert challenge.

Cons:
-No online multiplayer.  Only local multiplayer.
-Currently the player can die and restart any level on episode mode without penalty so that the episode leaderboards are like playing any individual level anyway, yet they do not record on the individual level leaderboard while playing in episode mode.  This makes the individual level concept/leaderboard quite redundent.
-On episode mode it is possible for a level to be impossible if the time is low enough entering the next level.  If this happens the player is forced to start the episode over and the game gives no warning when this happens.
-The story of the game is fairly bland.
-In the editor players can make impossible levels.

Opinion:
      N++ is a masterpiece, brilliant platformer.  The price of the game is dirt cheap for all the content in it.  If you are at all interested in platformers this is a must buy.  The game is focused on the platforming gameplay, not on the story so that doesn't matter much.  It is an absurd amount of content as it is yet more is planned to be added.  The flaws with individual level and episodes are minuscule and you have to go out of your way to discover these minor nitpicks.  They could not afford online Co-op.  If the game sells enough they will implement it.  The impossible levels in the editor are a definite nuisance but fortunately there are ways to sort levels by best or featured so this isn't obtrusive. 

Bottom line:
      N++ is brilliant and every bit as good as advertised.  If you don't enjoy this game it is because you don't like the platforming genre.  If that is the case it is not for you and neither is any platforming game but otherwise I guarantee you will love it.

For those unfamiliar with the N series, N++ is latest installment of a series of minimalistic, tough as nails platformers that emphasises precision and maintaining inertia through "episodes" of 5 short levels at a time. It is a thinking man's Super Meat Boy. The game is hilarious at times through subtle humor hidden in level names and layouts. There is a massive amount of content with over 1000 levels in the game and an easy to use level creator. Make no mistake, this game will kick your ass over and over.....and over again, but the difficulty curve seems more gentle than previous entries....at first. Controls are extremely tight to accommodate the hair-splitting precision needed for later levels.

As a longtime player of N+ back on XBLA and DS, I was pleasantly surprised to see it finally get a fitting sequel on PC. If you loved N+, get this game immediately. There are new types of blocks and a way of browsing created levels in addition to leaderboards that allow you to watch runs of the top players for each episode. This is useful for getting past the some of the seemingly impossible levels. 

It is beautiful, It is soul crushing, It is addictive, It is a classic
There's no online multiplayer, if that was a deciding point for you. Otherwise, [b]YES[/b]
This is about as pure as platforming gets.  It has everything it needs and nothing it doesn't.  The execution couldn't be better

I've been an N fan all my life. Playing 1.4 on the computer, then 2.0, playing through and beating N+ on DS, PSP (my fav version) and 200/200 on Xbox 360. Purchased N++ on PS4 when it released last year and was the primary reason why I purchased the console.

There's a reason why so many people have played and continue to purchase N games throughout the years:

You can not get a more pure platforming experience than N++.

It's pure skill; no powerups, no "the game cheated!!" it's on you - the player - to completely play the way of the ninja.

N++ maintains this pure skill aspect and throws in:

1) Crazy amount of stages
2) Fantastic soundtrack
3) Color customization options that are fun to play around with
4) Local co-op 
5) Online sharing and playing
6) Everything is leaderboards

When Metanet say there won't be a sequel I can absolutely believe it: I have no idea how they can further iterate N.

You like platformers? Want to get a ton of value? Like chasing scores? N++ is your jam.

Finally: the quintessential version of the game I spent so many hours playing in my formative platforming years, back on its home OS! Pros: gorgeous graphics, lovely music, tons of content, global rankings, user maps. Cons: tweaks aside, it's still fundamentally the same game it was 10 years ago. Whether you see that as a good thing or not depends on how much you love the original. As far as I'm concerned, the price is a steal!

N is a platforming game of sorts, where inertia and momentum are often a key factor in completing a level.  You kind of just have to try it to fully understand.  Thankfully, the original free flash game is still available to play online after all these years.  Run a google search for "N flash game" and N 2.0 should be the first result.

N++ is a version for people who want more.  More levels, more obstacles and "enemies", more modes including co-op and racing (but not online, which has upset some people)..  If you like a game that is challenging but fair, you'll probably enjoy it.  The controls are tight, and the physics of the movement of the character is a fun aspect of the game to get a 'feel' for.  You will actually feel yourself getting better at the game the more you play.

Keyboard controls have always worked fine for the original N, but of course this version supports controller, and I have grown quite fond of playing this way already.

All in all, this is a fine quality PC game.  It doesn't feel like a rough port of another version or anything.. it runs well, handles well, it's a significant upgrade content-wise and visually from the oldschool N, and I think it's worth the money, so I give it my recommendation.

[b]I've been playing N in some form or another since 2005[/b], starting in high school. After getting many of my friends hooked on it, we played it on and off in some form for years, throughout college and the rest of our lives. Then, a blank period, the Sony Years as N++ began to be made and then spent a year in PS4 exclusivity. Thankfully, we are past that dark time: N++ has come to its true home in all of its fatal gold-fueled metabolic glory.

[b]Do you like Super Meat Boy[/b]? N is the source for most of what made Meat Boy interesting, thematically and mechanically.
Do you hate Super Meat Boy? N is far more easily controlled, designed with a keyboard in mind, and has significantly shorter and more feature-dense levels without all of the bugs and clipping issues of SMB.

[b]Do you like ninjas[/b]? You are one, seeking gold to fuel your comically short lifespan as you clear room after room of skill-testing trials.
Do you hate ninjas? You're a bundle of abstract lines in a gorgeously minimalistic world, backed with fantastic music and displayed in any number of slick palettes.

[b]Do you like accessability[/b]? Cool: N++ has the menu options you desire, from rebinding to colorblind options, palette swaps of all shapes and sizes, secret options, and Numberwang. Oh, and the game is played with a whopping 3 buttons (4 if you enjoy resetting)

N++ is the latest and greatest evolution of one of the best platformers ever put to the digital screen. Hands down, I recommend it with 0 reservations or qualifications. Now excuse me: I need to go get my new friends from a decade down the line hooked on N++, to complete the cycle.

N++ is a great game and whilst it can be quite frustrating at times, I've thoroughly enjoyed it.

Pros:
- Comprehensive level design and number of levels for immersion, each level is different.
- Game has no skill ceiling and often gives you the choice between taking the easy path for a lower score or the harder path for a better score.
- It can be fun to get competitive with your friends and constantly improve your score to see who is the best at each episode.
- The soundtracks go along with the game quite well and are fun to listen to.
- The various colour schemes that you start off with and can unlock including changing the ninja's colour and headband colour offer some customization options for your experience.
- Co-op is awesome, and a great experience to have with a close friend.
- While it can be pretty frustrating and definitely time consuming it can also be quite a rewarding experience when you play an episode over and over again and finally get a good highscore.
- You can see other peoples replays if you get stuck and you can also watch your own replay of each episode for improvement and to enjoy watching your performance.
- Following the last point each replay will also display the time for each individual level in an episode so you can note what time you have to beat at each stage of an episode.
- Easy to use level editor for making custom levels and exploring new ideas, you can later publish these levels but remember that once you publish a level it will be deleted from your local storage and uploaded to the server.
- You can play any number of custom levels from players all around the world which makes for a great experience.

Cons/Bugs:
-Some people cheat and it's obvious when you look at the global leaderboard for some episodes.
-You can't see your friends' high score in the friends tab even if they are friends with you on steam and also own a copy of the game.
-Sometimes when you play an episode the game saves your highscore but later forgets you did that episode so you have to do that episode again even though your highscore on the server is still saved.
-Not a bug but I wish that there was an option that allowed your best offline score to be saved and uploaded when you are online again so that efforts aren't wasted when there are connection issues.

I remember playing N on computer many years ago when all I could play as a kid was browser games on my parent's computer.
Seeing this in the Steam Store brought a big smile upon my face.

And it plays just how I remember - it's brutal. Momentum is a big factor in how you move around the levels. 
Want to make your walljump even bigger? Run against the wall with full speed and then jump off.

Still not enough? Well, then run down a ramp with accelerating speed and you can keep that speed if you know how to move around the level. 

Then there's a pretty large variety of dangers like electricity gates and landmines.
But also more intelligent enemies like auto turrets with homing missiles, or sniper turrets that have mild movement prediction coming with their aim. Or mobile enemies that usually only circle around terrain, but will charge into your direction if there is a line of sight.
This game can easily compete with repeatedly praised, more recent platformers like Celeste.

I know I'm a bit biased here, but for me N++ is my favorite platformer of all time.

Pure platforming built around a set of simple obstacles and intuitive physics, but an extreme challenge to master. The stark presentation only highlights how refined the gameplay of N++ is, and the stunning variety of levels offers spectacular replay value. As someone who exhaustively played the original N, this game is practically flawless.

The game is a fairly simple platformer, but the levels can get brutal, though usually not frustratingly difficult. The controls are very tight, practically by necessity, and are surprisingly powerful despite the controls also being so simple. The game also has an insane number of levels and potentially hundreds of hours of content. The only real downside to this game is that a few of the unlockable color schemes can be a bit hard on the eyes, though this isn't much of a problem. If you like difficult platformers, or can put up with dying over and over just to beat that one level, then definitely buy this, it's very much worth the money.

Controls keep your momentum from walljumps, jumps and running.

*I've completed the campaign on the original PS4 release, so add about 40 hours to the play time of this review if it's relevant to you.*

Since its origins as a shareware flash game, the N series has consistently impressed me with its minimalist design which conceals finely tuned, complex mechanics. N++, the third and purportedly final entry, takes all of the strengths of the previous entries and distills them into the definitive experience. 

If you've ever enjoyed an N game or some of their descendants (Super Meat Boy, Dustforce, etc.), then your money and time will be well-spent here. If dubious, just download the free original and get a feel for the basics, knowing that in ++ the developers have strengthened and refined that design.

Though it offers a breadth of content (over 2000 levels, user created content, cooperative and competetive local-mulitplayer,) N++ sacrifices no attention to detail. The spartan, vector-based aesthetic exemplifies and serves the minimalist design well, always putting concise, clear communication above extravagance without coming at the cost of sleek style. 

N++'s physics-based controls (which are at times more like piloting a graceful glider than running and jumping) may not come as intuitively as a Super Mario or Rayman Legends, but once you grow accustomed to them, you'll likely find they reward practice and patience more than any competitor.

And that's NumberWang.

To help me explain this game, I will benchmark it against Mario. In a prime 2D Mario game, the win conditions are:
 - your knowledge of every enemy and object and their interactions
 - your feel for Mario's acceleration curve

In N++ your win conditions are:
 - your knowledge of every enemy's behavior (not many enemies).
 - your feel for Ninja's acceleration curve
 - your feel for Ninja's vertical momentum gain per jump
 - your planned momentum harvesting route

Even though N++ only gives you a jump button, it feels so much richer because it has momentum play that also happens to be consistent, intuitive, and so perfectly tuned. It may have non of Mario's charm, but I think it makes up for it in its criminally great soundtrack, massive library of levels, and much faster browsing of stages made by people online. Not to mention the cool feature of watching any of the top 20 replays of any level, whether offline or online.

N++ is purely a platformer, and I don't care much for games like that these days, but this is a very special case. In N++, there are over 4000 levels to race through, collect all the gold in and die many times in. Besides its levels, N++ also has a wonderful soundtrack, unlockable color schemes for levels and headband styles for your ninja, leaderboards, and a level editor for creating your own levels and sharing them online.

It seems that when you're making a game, you can either build with the features you already have or add new ones, and for N++, the developers chose to focus almost purely on building with the features they had. This may seem like a weird choice, but when playing N++ the gameplay might just be perfect. There's nothing I could think of that would be a really meaningful addition to make the gameplay better.

So, I've had a crappy joke serving as my review for a while since I didn't quite know what to say about this game. As of the time I'm writing this, I'm a few steps away from earning 100% in N++. Heck, I'm tackling the hardest challenge in the game right now, which seasoned players will know simply as "eeny." The grind has been an emotional experience, so I figured now would be a great time to revisit my thoughts.

Let me start with the traditional blanket statement: N++ is the best platformer I have played, and will ever play. Though I have many reasons, most of them can be boiled down to "damn this game is so hard, but damn this game feels so good."

The game embodies "intrinsic motivation" through its momentum-based mechanics and superb design. The three-button control scheme lures you down the rabbit hole, narrow in scope but deeper than you could ever fully fathom. The multi-layered design accompanies the gameplay well, creating one of the smoothest skill curves I've ridden, if sheerly because of the game's breadth of content. Stuck on something? Not to worry, there are thousands of other levels you can try.

To delve into spoilers for a moment: [spoiler]challenges are such a cool way to add more flavour and difficulty to the content in the game. A level could go from being complete filler to busting your balls for several hours straight, or your gradual skill improvement could tame a level that previously gave you a hard time. The process of discovering these challenges and working your way through their cruel and creative solutions extends the game's lifespan far past what most 2D platformers attempt to achieve.[/spoiler]

Well, let's say that completion doesn't appeal to you. Not to worry, maybe another activity will tickle your fancy. You've got plenty to pick from: co-op, highscoring, speedrunning, competitive racing, deathless runs, playing userlevels, level editing — hell, you can even make your own colour palettes and sound effects.

This leads me to another exceptional asset this game benefits from: its community. It may seem odd to comment on the community of a game without online play, but the more you strive toward improving your skill at this game, the more likely you are to meet members of the devoted and talented band of ninjas who spearhead the modern image of N++. This community goes beyond supporting other players; during the year I've spent with them, I've witnessed an inspiring culture of empathy, vulnerability, and terrible memes about the ninja having a thick ass. In a game so relentlessly difficult, it's stunning to look back on how much it has humanized me through all the friends I met. I would have given up several hundred hours earlier without them. 

If a game like Celeste embodies what it's like to scale a mountain, N++ embodies what it's like to break a mountain with your bare hands. It'll take a long, long time. It'll take loads of effort with seemingly no hope of success at times. Every layer you shatter reveals another, sturdier layer underneath. But you will always have the power to tear that mountain down. You'll feel yourself become stronger and, no matter how long the mountain endures, you'll claw back with the motivation to turn that rock into a damn toothpick.

A good and fast-paced platformer that requires high levels of precision and skill to get through, with a wide variety of levels. I still have yet to get through it, but I would say this version is definitely worth putting a bit of money into. The original version was free, but had significantly less content and I think this can definitely be worth it. Time to give it another go!

Nostalgia trip for a game nearly two decades old. If you are one of those 2D precision platformer freaks like me, you know N as one of the precision platforming and physics platforming OGs from the flash games era. It's a classic for sure. The simplicity of the game's mechanics, goals and controls are its strenghts, aswell as the momentum based physics. The slippery movement and air control being incredibly floaty might seem off putting at first, but quickly reveals itself as one of its greatest assets, being one of the major component of making you feel like you truly are a ninja, in spite of the overly (yet beautifully) minimalistic graphic style leaving much to the imagination.

The fact that the servers for this game are not up anymore should deem this game free to play. Not only does the lack of servers cut a lot of content from the game as custom content was is one of the selling points, but even with the "Submit Scores" setting disabled, it is impossible to progress past a set of stages without Alt-F4'ing as it still tries to submit the scores with no way to stop it. If you enjoy insanely difficult platformers, this game is 100% for you. Super clean game that actually takes some work on the mechanics to gain the skill necessary to pull of certain challenges. Best platformer mechanics I've ever played.

This game is chock-full of pure, challenging, platformy goodness. The momentum-based movement is taken into full consideration with the level design; most levels (of which there are thousands) have unique layouts that are hand-crafted to be difficult, but readily understandable; coins are enticing due to their direct usefulness and not solely for collecting's sake; the music sets the mood without distracting from gameplay, and the clear-cut graphical style makes it easy to analyze each level and formulate a plan. If you want a platformer in pure form, definitely give this a go.

THAT SAID, there are certainly issues I have with this game. The further you delve into the extensive grid of levels, the more you will start to find outliers. While the vast majority of levels feel original and justified, there are a smattering of levels with cookie-cutter design, long-haul repetitiveness, and coins that feels less like a worthy challenge and more like a laughably absurd spike of time and effort. If you don't get that impression, then, thankfully, you're less cynical than me.

Completing this game 100% is quite a task. I would dare to call it a wholly ridiculous task, due to some of the coin collecting. Many coins feel like they were placed as a callous slap to the face of the player, set in areas that demand inhuman levels of precision - and the nerves to perform these feats of skill many minutes into a level, risking a painful amount of failure with the slightest mistake. And sometimes there's just a monumental grid of coins that looks like it would take all day to grab. Combine that with an already perilous level structure, and you've got yourself a slog of a level.

Am I complaining that it's too hard? Yeah, a bit. And it's fair if you ignore this review because of that. But whether or not a relatively easy level with half a million coins spilled across the board is fair, I just can't find any fun in it.

Play this game casually if you're seeking a rough, tough platforming experience that'll keep you busy for hours, but I sincerely advise you to avoid completing this game 100% if you don't  know exactly what you're in for. Whether or not you can do it, I don't know that it will be worth it.

It's unfortunate, because I recommend this game for the ridiculous, ground-breaking platforming that it is. And with even more levels than ever, this is absolutely a need for anyone that loves the pain of mastering a platforming game like Meat Boy or even I Wanna Be The Guy.

But the saves corrupt, and the cloud save doesn't work. And the dev doesn't particularly seem to care about that.

How are you supposed to enjoy a game when 30hrs later it will wipe your entire progress?

Can you enjoy a multiplayer experience with no servers?

Then how can you enjoy a game designed to make you work for every inch you progress, only to randomly delete it and steal it away from you?

Sure you can backup your profile but that's not the point. You shouldn't have to implement band-aid fixes on a game because the developer couldn't be bothered to finish their work.

Imagine ur standing in front of a MASSIVE guy. Homie is completely ripped, 8 feet tall, dudes practically a nordic viking. On top of all that, hes also hot as hell. Now suppose god throws you a stick and is like "ok now kill that guy with this stick". That is practically my N++ experience.

Now you might be wondering, how in the hell would you kill this guy with just a stick? I mean, dude generates enough force to blow Jupiter out of existence just by flexing his pectorals. And yes, I agree with this statement, but you've gotta understand dear reader, that if you poke that large lad with the stick for a long enough period of time, at some point it will begin to hurt. By no means are you gonna get it done instantly, but as long as you persist and have a good mentality, you will eventually pierce his flesh.

I'm writing this review as I finish solo mode, which is essentially me cutting off all 4 limbs and the torso off this guy. Still have coop and race left, but solo the bulk of the experience. New players begin the game and typically get overwhelmed by the seemingly infinite amount of content, and likely drop the game after finishing intro and maybe a row or two. They think that no matter what, they can never finish this beastly game. Trust me I know the feeling, because starting out I had the same thoughts. Regardless, if you just play little by little, poke the beast to death bit by bit, you will notice steady, good progress, and suddenly the game will not feel as massive anymore. I've really found that the majority of this game is a mental challenge. If you go into each day with the mentality that you WILL beat a few levels, then within a few months you will notice that you too have chopped off maybe a limb or two. But enough about this weird ass analogy, lets talk about the game.

I'd like to think I'm a seasoned platformer player, and coming out of this incredible campaign I can say with confidence that this the most raw platforming experience ive ever had. The learning curve is surprisingly massive; just when you think you are getting good, the game will throw some new precision mechanic at you to master, and man am I all for it. It really does feel like metanet tried everything when designing the levels, and so you will have the opportunity to do literally EVERYTHING in this game. The controls and physics may feel awkward at first, but at some point it begins to feel incredibly natural, like you are one with da ninja. The experience has been completely positive for me, of course with the exception of a few nasty levels. However, this pool of levels is small compared to the amount of great stuff, so don't let it deter you!

Needless to say, this game has been great, and I have been pretty sad that the campaign is over. Doesn't even feel like its been that long since ive started. And thats why I urge you all to give this game a shot; to experience that feeling of wonder that comes from playing this games campaign for the first time. The road may seem unending, and the ripped guy may seem to never fall, but slowly and surely things will swing in your favor, and I promise you that.

N: Definitive Edition. If you've never paid for this 12 year old flash classic, now is the time. Lethal platforming across thousands of levels with tight controls, all to an A+ soundtrack. Highly recommended to anyone who enjoyed Super Meat Boy.

I would argue that this is one of the greatest games ever. Well worth the price; Great Gameplay; Great Community; In short, it's near perfect, as far as 2 dimensions go. The only thing it is missing is Online Multiplayer.

In a little more depth, if you've never played a game in the series:

In my opinion, the greatest aspect of this game is the challenge. In essense, it isn't too challenging once you get the basics down. You move around expertly designed levels, momentum is key, and certain things kill you. You have 90 seconds to complete an episode of 5 levels, and the gold coins scattered around the levels give you 2 extra seconds each.

The majority of the episodes are not too challenging to complete in 90 seconds; What makes it difficult are the tight controls; You clip corners quite often here; One wrong move, and you're dead, falling, losing momentum, etc... Combine that, and a subtle play on your desire to be better; faster; and you have one of the greatest platforming games of all time. As is the standard for this series,; There is also a level creator and sharing capabilities.

I've waited since the Original for there to be a Sequel on PC (Mostly, one with controller support) and now that it is here, i'm far from dissapointed. Sure, the lack of Online, Real time Multiplayer (Survivals, Races, Co-Op) is a little saddening, but i do personally enjoy the Solo aspect far too much to not buy this game, regardless.

I would easily say this is one of the best games you can buy for under $15.

I've been playing N in one form or another since I was a kid, it seems only fair the devs get some of my money now. 

This isn't at all a departure from the series, this is N Classic with more polish, new elements, new maps, a map editor, better music, and same-system co-op. 

Same controls, same atmosphere, and same butt-clenching stress as before. Sound good? Great.

If you're new to the series, the older games are available online still, check em out.

Don't let anybody tell you this is like Super Meat Boy. The controls are similar, but Super Meat Boy manufactures difficulty by forcing you to move through the map at high speeds, and swinging obstacles into the field of view quickly - so you essentially have to memorize the map by dying a certain number of times. Or maybe your reaction time is way better than mine, who am I to judge (Synth)

Here, you see the entire map at once, and once you have the hang of enemy movement patterns, you can plan your route before the timer even starts, and it's not uncommon to finish a map in one gloriously satisfying, white-knuckle first try, barely squeezing through gaps in mines and racing past homing missiles.

It's... Just so good. I hope the community map making takes off.

Ah, good old N. This game is quite nostalgic for me. For those who know and love N, you won't be disappointed. All the good parts of N are still here. It's basically an extended and polished version of N. It has plenty of new and interesting levels and a some nice competition. Also all the old levels are still there to revisit.

However, some of the things the game added aren't that perfect. Nothing mayor, but I still do dislike these aspects of the game

- Some colour schemes are so vibrant they simply hurt my eyes.
- Because you get some sort of achievement if you get all the gold in a level the levels where they just spam goldies mid air do quite suck if you try to get that achievement. And as a completionist that bugs me to no end.
- players can make levels, that might sound like a pro, but it's mostly a con to me. The game has only been out a few hours and I already found a golden swastika.
- no built-in levels for racing, thus the racing is just a pile of uninspired player created content that is either bad, or way to hard.
- the "you suck" stage. In the race mode after you take to long or press a button the game will enter the you suck stage. In that stage it will slowly make the level easier to get someone to win the race. That's all fine and dandy, but when I'm getting ticked of because a level is to hard don't go tell me I suck. That's a sure-fire way to annoy me to the point I ALT+F4.
- When you win a race you can be a rocket to hinder your foes, but the rocket tends to fly into a wall before I even had the chance to steer.

It's a great game. But I'd advise to stay away from the racing. And don't try to hard on getting all the gold, it can ruin the fun.

I absolutely love it. I've only played the Nintendo DS version and I can't really remember that one too well, but this game is incredible.

* The controls are tight - for a platformer that has "floaty" controls, you definitely feel like you have a lot of control over your character, even with high momentum
* The levels are creative and well designed 
- You can always play more levels from the online community
* The difficulty is balanced - the game does get hard, but 
- it's never impossible 
- for ones that you feel are impossible, just leave it and go to another level
* The soundtrack really helps you concentrate on the platforming
* Game keeps changing up the enemies, so things never really get old
* This seems like a weird thing to praise the game for, but you can actually change the colour of the game. I didn't think I'd like it but it's actually quite a cool feature.

The only negative thing I can think of is that the community maps feel nearly impossible, but I guess that's because of my inexperience with the game so far. I can easily recommend it to anyone who just wants to kick back with a nice, challenging platformer.

Been playing N game since it was still only a small internet flash game, over 10 years have passed and I still cannot get enough of it. What keeps the game so interesting is the level editor and playing the thousands of levels created by every other player! This game just never gets boring!

Very great game that I've been waiting on for quite some time. As a fan of the original N, having this version on the PC is like a homecoming of sorts. This is truly the perfection of platforming and of movement. Might as well write some pros and cons for anyone who wants to read them.

Pros:
Great Soundtrack
Many different color schemes
Genuinely challenging levels (generally not due to "troll design" or controls being difficult)
Intuitive controls
Sublime level design
Local Multiplayer can be extremely fun
Hundreds of hours of content
Minimalist aesthetic makes it easy to understand what's going on, even when many things can be happening.
It "feels" great: the momentum, the movement, the platforming, the design all come together for one cohesive, fun experience.

Neutrals:
Can take a bit of getting used to the momentum and basic mechanics (a bit different from most platformers) if you haven't played N (which is free on the web), but N++ has a series of tutorial levels that help you grasp the core mechanics and features of the game much better than N did. Pro-tip: read the level titles!

Cons:
More people don't already own this game.

Overall: I thoroughly enjoy this game and would highly recommend anyone even remotely interested in this game, or any fans of platformers in general, to pick this gem up (it's only $12 until the 1st!).

This is flat out the most polished platformer I've ever played. The physics and tight controls are wonderfully reactive, and the level design is creative, sadistic, and meticulous (I'd comare it favorably to Super Meat Boy).

Gameplay enhancements from previous entries are subtle (momemntum boosters, laser turrets, and a few other elements), but the aforementioned excellet level design gets a lot of mileage out of different permutations of the new and old elements, adding a lot of depth. Best addition (IMHO) is the soudtrack, which is extensive for the first time in the series, and quite good. The level editor (a major draw for me) is also substantially improved over the previous entries, and is a good deal easier to use.

I've seen a few folks questioning the pricing of this game, cosidering it is very similar to the original, free version that is available. TBH, the free version is still awesome, and you should totally play it if you're not sure about dropping $15, though in my oppition this updated version is totally worth the 15 dollar price tag, considering the 2000+ levels it comes with, the extra layes of polish, and the soundtrack (which would easily be worth $10 itself).

So yeah, get it, it's good.

I have to admit that I've played the original flash game N way back when I went to school and loved it, but wasn't able enough to finish most of the game.
Even back then, it had some of the best level design I have ever seen in a platformer regardless of the minimal controls (jump, left, right, suicide).
Then some time later, N+ was released for the PSP and NDS, sadly locking me out as a sworn PC gamer.
Now recently, N++ came to my attention as it appeared on my Steam store page.
Even though I have high standards for a new N game released on PC, it didn't disappoint me in any way and impressed me by maintaining its original vector graphics look which I think was lost on the handheld N+ version.
The level design is fantastic (and includes most, if not all of the previous titles), the soundtrack just as good and it has timeless looking vector graphics with loads of unlockable colour schemes.
I would absolutely recommend this to any fan of platformer games, but would tell them to try the free original N first to see if they can handle the difficulty.

This game provides an ever increasing difficulty that is enjoyable with or without friends. Local coop is usually overlooked nowadays, but N++ has an entire coop campaign, with different levels than solo, this gets around the pitfall many local multi-player games run into: balancing drop in/out coop for solo play. This game does not get easier with a friend, you will both struggle. It is glorious.

This games controls are the definition of easy to pick up, hard to master. You essentially move left and right, and jump, but theres really a lot more to it. The features of this game are overall not complicated, but very fun to play with. Visuals are pretty minimalistic, but attractive, and there are a lot of color schemes to choose from. Soundtrack is pretty good.

This also has a lot more replayability than you'd expect for a momentum-based 2d platformer. There's no story, but there are over 4000 levels, every one of them handmade and varying in difficulty from really easy to really hard. Its amazing how consistently good the level design is. Myself, Ive only beaten a small chunk of them. There's also a level editor with level sharing capabilities. I love being able to create my own stuff, but that being said the editor UI feels very clunky and the level sharing in general is missing a lot of core features that really aught to exist (such as being able to save user levels for later, or delete your own published levels off the server).

Some people will find that the game is overall too simple, and that's fine. But what it does, it does really well in my opinion. Only other thing I can think to say bad about it is that navigating menus feels clunky and unintuitive, but this is overall a great game.

Easily over 250 hours of content if you include all levels, attempting to collect all gold, and then begin going for the secret challenges in each level. There is simply an unparalleled amount of content here; you will not find more official content per dollar in a platformer (unless the game is, of course free, in which that ratio is infinite).
This, of course, only applies if you are a fan of the game itself. I can assure you; if you enjoy 2D platforming with a challenge level similar to that of more recent "difficulty revival" games, i.e. Super Meat Boy, VVVVVV, JumpJet Rex and especially Dustforce DX, you will love this game. 
The minimalist style is accompanied with extraordinarily tight and manipulable physics that, even a hundred hours in, you will still be using in new and varied ways. Each level has smart design that allows for multiple different playstyles and every obstacle contained within is usually placed in an intelligent, difficult-yet-fair manner. The sheer number of levels in the N++ Solo tab alone is enough to be worth 15 dollars, but there's seven times that in the final product (including the co-op and race modes).
This game is the quintessential platformer. It will chew you up and spit you out... and you'll love every second of it.

After being a huge fan of the flash games N and N2, it was a real blast playing this latest incarnation... sadly my times on the leaderboards rank about the 13000 mark, meaning 12999 other people were faster than me, but that doesn't matter. Momentum-based platformers really impress me, and there is none finer than N++.


The minimalist design is still here, and the hand-crafted levels vary from simple to notoriously difficult.


There is nothing so difficult that it cannot be finished in 5 to 10 attempts, but the best thing about this game is the palpable sense of improvement (very much like Dustforce DX). I am about 50% through the main N++ stages, and I have enjoyed every second so far, the slowly morphing ambient background beats are so wonderful, that sometimes you simply forget they are playing (which is weird, as some are heavy on the bass, and I have a very decent subwoofer)... a sign of perfect music choice.


I know I have yet to hit the truly "difficult" stages, but I am not frightened. I actually look forward to them... which is not something often said about precision platformers.


I give this game a solid 9.5/10


It is only surpassed by the likes of Super Meat Boy and Dustforce DX, and mainly because of the randomness in difficulty of stages... not technically the game itself.


Whether it's shimmying up narrow gaps, or making seemingly impossible screen-wide jumps, this game is a real gem

Metanet has redeemed themselves (mostly) with this game after pissing me off relentlessly with the original N, then churning out a piss-easy XBox 360 game (N+), and then ultimately ripping my soul from my body and shredding it with their upgrade to N (NReality.)

It took me 2.5 years to beat 95% of NReality, and then a computer crash wiped all of my data. The emotional turmoil I experienced after that was unprecedented. I subsequently rid my computer of anything resembling N and told myself I would never play it again.

But little did I know that I still had a registered account with Metanet, and one day I received an e-mail about N++ being on Steam. I was hesitant, to say the least, but the price seemed reasonable, and the game itself did look awesome. This was a chance for me to redeem myself, so I went for it.

The game is awesome. It's not as ruthless as NReality, but it's still a huge challenge. There are enough gimmicks and enough new elements that keep me engaged. They still have user created levels at the ready in case I decide to try out a level that someone else made, and the music is simply amazing.

This game really has a soul. Nice to see that Metanet did something good with it after they tore it from me.

Only negative I have about the game is that there's no online co-op. Co-op is strictly local, which is difficult when you're the only one in the household who plays games like this. But from what I understand, they had limited resources, and had to decided between EITHER online co-op or user-created levels. Given the choice, I'd say they chose correctly.

N++ is, in my honest opinion, the pinacle of 2D platforming. In my experience, there is no momentum based platforming more refined. With each jump it is clear what the trajectory is determined upon. This predictability is what makes a game that is brutally savage at times still fun. 

Despite that, the earlier levels are well put together and introduce the enemies carefully to allow those new to the genre a chance to learn at a fair pace. It takes 2 minutes to learn everything this game has to offer but I would feel arrogant saying I've mastered it after all this time.

++ Tight controls (slow but it feels like you are in control)
++ Good graphics (like the style a lot)
++ Evil levels (over [strike]2,000[/strike] [b]4,000[/b] or so of them which is terrifying)
++ Nice music (a bunch of chill electronic songs)
++ Level editor & online sharing (nice)

-- Sometimes doesn't work on a few computers

9/10 really good

If you like your platformers, this is a must-have. Twitch-edge platforming at it's sharpest, most infuriating and most rewarding.

If you've happened across N or N+, then you know what to expect - this is all that and so much more. If you haven't, then just know this is the best so far (and that's a very high bar).

The game has inherited many features from its previous series (N and N plus). On the perspective by just looking at it, it's fun to play and the simple controls works great with keyboards. Your primary objective is to reach for the key card and find your way to the exit. If you want to, you may challenge yourself to collect all gold blocks in the level without dying. Its almost no different than any other platformers, but what makes it special is that it has very unique UI color schemes and awesome techno musics. The music helps you to concentrate while playing and you never feel bored. You kept dying again and again but in result you won't want to give up on playing anymore because you are so into the game by just listening the musics. The game also rewards you new color schemes after completing a certain number of stages and each of them is very pleasant looking. Clearly this game has a distinctive way to express its beauty.

The game is predicated on tough jumps and controls, and its very own physics system that's built on momentum. All you can really do with your ninja avatar is run and jump, but you must be able to use acceleration and precise leaps to land on your desired place. By trying to complete the level you will be experienceing countless deaths and resulting successes eventually makes you feel that you have really achieved a lot of things. The game tells you to complete each level within 90 seconds and picking up gold along the way to increase your timer. If you are to become a hardcore player (like me), you will likely want to collect all the gold up.

N++ has a huge number of campaign levels (2000+) and even more levels uploaded by the players all around the world. While I am still struggling on completing first part of Solo levels I still can't believe that my total play time has reached 5 hours(believe me, its not short compared to other games). The Co-op levels requires 2-4 players to play, and there will be parts where you have to kill yourself into hazards to make a way for your friend to reach to the exit. But usually it's pretty much the same with solo levels (sometimes you can complete a Co-op level all by yourself). You can also play the uploaded levels as well, or you can make levels of your own and upload them like others. Unfortunately it's a huge dissapointment that there is no online play for the Co-op levels.

N++ might lack online play and feel like more of the same, but it's pretty much everything a platformer fan could want out of a sequel. It's still challenging, it has sh*tloads of levels, and it's a hell of alot of fun to play.

Revamped design, impressive soundtrack, what's not to like? Almost nothing looks the same as it used to, and the game is better off for it. If you're a fan of the originals, or generally into challenging 2D platformers, you'll enjoy this game.

Let me tell you a story.

When I was a kid, back in the days when Steve Jobs was still alive, when I only barely understood where babies came from, when I read books about Forestclan and Firestar, when the only video game I actually physically owned was Myst, there were flash games. These were, mostly, the only games that you could share or show to other people. And among your Fancy Pants Man and Run, there was N. One little ninja VS a seemingly impossible number of levels, fueled by gold and a passion for juking rockets.

I played the eff out of it. And then, in time, I came to the edge of my abilities. The limits to my perseverence. Eventually, I stopped, but not before enjoying it half to death. There were a few other times, in later years, when I came back to it on a memory trip, downloaded it off the webpage, and kept a tally of deaths as I strived for 100% completion. But again, I eventually became overwhelmed by life and such.

And now N++ is here. Faster. Simpler. Bigger and, I will say, better. And now, with tunes. It is the essential N experience, and I am so happy it exists. I can feel myself entering that platforming Zen as I work my way though, a rock garden full of mines and golden flowers. And I continue to be reminded:

Simple does not mean Easy. Hard does not mean the opposite of Fun.
Love this game, the simple controls and endless fun make it a great way to pass the time.

A fantastic remastering of N. Adds new mechanics (and local multiplayer!) while staying true to the original gameplay. The controls and handling are great. Kudos to the devs for continuing this game over a decade later.

N++ is the single best platformer i have ever, and likely ever will play, for many reasons.

firstly, lets start off with the core of a platformer, the control, which initially felt floaty and broken, but as time went on i began to see the essence of why it is perfect for this game, the way the physics works allows for complex movement and also simpler movement at the same time and momentum doesn't carry the way a conventional platformer does and because of it, the games geometry and level design always seems to fit and readily to offer varying speeds and types of movement in each level, in addition due to the slo-mo feel of the ninja it allows the player to have fine grained control which feels more satisfying and smoother to play compared to most platformers.

the next huge thing N++ gets right is the level design and the entities within which complement how everything is set up within the game, the obstacles are always setup in unique ways which aren't afraid to experiment to create interesting ideas and really explore every nook and cranny in terms of what is possible without adding hundreds of enemies and spamming, and sometimes they do add hundreds of enemies, but guess what, never once does it feel cheap or overly frustrating, the way everything is set up is so the player can feel a sense of growth and that they've learnt something from each death they have, these entities have such a large palette that it creates a huge number of synergies which offers varying context for obstacles, for example a rocket combined with a floor chasing drone forces you to jump but to also make sure you're not flying a rocket into yourself, and that's just 1 example of the thousands of ideas which are thrown your way as you play.

the game also has an insurmountable amount of content to it, with at the base level requiring a player to simply collect gold or clear the level, and as the game goes on it introduces secret challenges which massively expands the depth of almost every level in the game, requiring things from very abstract movement to routing things differently to the first time you played, making the game a huge learning experience and constantly testing the players skill, which makes for a very engaging and entertaining experience, not only compensating for people who want to enjoy a casual experience, but also for the hardcore veterans of platformers; something i want to express greatly is just how creative these challenges are, some levels are changed ENITRELY based off of 1 challenge condition added to the level and again combined with all the other elements in the game, it allows for a huge variance in the challenges you'll face so nothing will feel repetitive.

another great point of the game is its OST, visual design and SFX design, the ost is a mix of loads of tracks which all fit the relaxed yet intense vibe of the game although it is short enough to get repetitive after a while but still is a great soundtrack nevertheless, the graphics are something i feel are EXTREMELY underappreciated, because they are very minimal it allows for gameplay to be read ahead of time and quickly too which fits the design the game is going for, enemies are made very distinct to platforms and other elements which are harmless, this is shared across all palettes which switch the color scheme of the game while still keeping the distinction of everything no matter what color scheme you're using! similarly the sound effects i feel is easily overlooked as they're simple sounds which fit whatever enemy is approaching or whatever the ninja has just touched, and they add a sense of livliness to each level as something as simple as a rocket launcher firing sends an instant message to the player and it all blends together nicely to give a very aestically pleasing theme to the game.

also something i feel that is a huge positive in the game is that there is no luck or rng, everything is based purely off of cycles or is determined by the players actions meaning that the frustration factor for me felt much lower, as any mistake made i wasn't blaming something cheap or something i couldn't do anything about but rather i did something wrong and i should figure out what it was and why i made said mistake, in essence the design of N++ is made so that you feel a huge sense of overcoming a challenge of your own volition compared to just getting lucky.

as of the time of writing this review, i have 100% completed the game in its entirety and i felt writing this review any sooner would be a huge injustice to the game as pretty much any clever idea you can think of for a level gimmick was explored in some way or another, and let me say it never got old, 150 hours in i felt i'd seen it all then 300 hours in, then 500 and it just never stopped until i was finally done with everything and i felt very satisfied that the developers knew exactly what  made something unique and stick out, and this especially applies to the secret tabs and their levels, they are expetional examples of how secret levels should be done with them being even more gimmicky and unusually designed than the normal sets of levels.

however with any good game, there are always flaws and ill try to keep my criticisms to a minimum since i adore this game dearly, firstly hardcore generally is unenjoyable, having to beat 25 levels deathless is pretty yucky as is, but because difficulty is ordered by row and not column it meant the difficulty of these columns feels a bit sporadic and can be either easy or randomly hard simply due to the fact that difficulty isn't entirely ordered this way.

needing to complete co-op mode without an online multiplayer function ingame is a bit counterintuitive, since those on console are at a massive disadvantage if they have no-one who they can play local co-op with, although the developers have explained their reasoning behind why it isn't it and they really want to, for now i do have to mark it as a negative point ;-; but a positive linked to this is the community is so warmingly welcoming and helpful that people are willing to lend a helping hand, and i'd have never made it to 100% without them, truly i mean it when i say the N++ community is the best community i have ever been in.

and possibly the greatest flaw the game has, is save file corruption, especially with a game of this size and caliber, and although ive never had to deal with it myself i can't imagine how it feels to lose hundreds or even thousands of hours of progress due to being unaware of the fact that save files are known to randomly corrupt, meaning any competionist is required to make frequent backups to avoid the risk of losing everything.

with all the negatives out of the way though, the game is an absolute masterpiece and is about as close to perfection as a platformer will ever get, and i would recommend it to absolutely anyone ever no matter your skill at games as i think N++ is a game that anyone can take something away from, but with it being a niche of platformers, and a niche within platformers themselves i could understand why someone may not feel the same way as i.

N, the way of the Ninja, is a classic game that I have been playing for quite some time now, starting all the way back to when I was in grade school playing on Flash sites.
 
With each new installment of N, the only thing added is levels and visuals.
N->N+: The game no longer looks like a free flash game.
N+->N++: Added cool colors and music!
N++ plays just like N, from all those years ago.

N++ is hard and is my favorite 2-D platformer. I play it mostly between classes or when I need a quick break. Along with new levels, N++ includes all the old missions from N, N+/XBL/PSN/DS, so it's a good legacy collection. Oh, and I can't forget there are also custom level creator. What differentiates N from other platformers is momentum in the movement. If you haven't played an N game before, this will frustrate you at first. Keep trying, and once you get the hang of jumping, it's super satisfying. $15 is a fair price, and if you see it on sale ($7 rn), buy it.

[b] What I love about this game: [/b]

[list]
    [*]Only 3 buttons during gameplay (Left, Right and Jump).
    [*]Smooth movement that takes getting used to at first but once you have mastered it you wish all other games had it.
    [*]The main game offers a ridiculous amount of content and has some of the coolest and most interesting level design I have ever seen.
    [*]Appealing minimal aesthetics.
    [*]Amazing local multiplayer experiences (both co-op and race).
    [*]Awesome editor and mapping community. Despite there only being about 40 players online at a time, the high-scoring is always super competitive on new community levels.
    [*]Awesome underground techno OST curated by the devs. This OST changed my life.
    [*]I love that there is no side-scrolling, the whole level is always on one screen.
    [*]Friendly community on discord.
[/list]

[b] What could be improved: [/b]

The game is really really good as it is, the following are only things I've felt after putting 1000+ hours into the game.

[list]
    [*]I've always wanted more than one playable character. Maybe a jetpack dude or something. The level editor is just so nice that it feels like a waste to not have more characters in this game.
    [*]There could also be more enemies, items, etc.
    [*]If this game had online multiplayer, my life would be complete.
[/list]

--

In conclusion I totally recommend this game. It has been such a great outlet for my creativity because of making levels. This game is the epitome of minimal game design. There is always the right amount of stuff going on.
The physics really make this game great! If you like platformers, then you going to need this game.

N++ is *absolutely brutal*. However, if you're the type to enjoy tough as nails platforming, this will totally give you your money's worth. This is my go to when I want to just play something for a little bit but not get super invested.

The presentation is great, the songs are perfectly chosen. Slap on some headphones and get immersed in the grind.

That being said, the older levels (from the original N, for example) are definitely superior in my opinion. The reliance on the stupid thing that creates a clone of you gets *real* old real fast; it just artificially inflates the challenge.

Still, there's tons of content here outside that, and the community stuff is always a blast. It's worth buying, 100%.

The best and most difficult platformer out there. The premise is simple, you play as a lill ninja who has to get gold and get out. This game was made some time ago and perfected over the years. [*]PUMPIN' BEATS
[*]Community content is available, you know what that means... The game... will never... N'd
[/list]
[h1]Cons[/h1][list]
[*]None, for what it is, it is perfectly what it should be
[/list]

This is the most challenging game I have ever played. It is tough, it makes me scream and cry, it feels impossibly hard at times. But it has earned being like that. It's never truly frustrating. The ridiculous perfectness of the graphics, the soundtrack, the level design, and most importantly the controls is something no other game will ever be able to emulate. So when I fail a level for the 983rd time, I might be done for the day, but I'm not done for good. Because it still feels like a worthwhile challenge, and not something that is just hard for the sake of being hard, which usually just means "unfair" these days. Twitchy controls, stupid level-design, these are things that make me stop playing games, because then it's just insulting. N++ makes a fool of me, but it does it in the most eloquent and respectful way and all I can and want to do is return the favor and push myself further when starting the 984th attempt.

N++ is one of the best 2D platformers I've ever played. It's easy to play, difficult to master a design idea that should be standard in not just every platformer but ever game ever. I digress though. This game is perfect for pick up & play nature. Although I have 17 hours in this game at the time of writing (will be much more later on but oh well). Most of my play sessions consist of 15-30 minutes, an hour at most. I can just hop in, play levels & move on with my day. This game can be difficult at times but the control in this game is so air-tight that any fuck ups are on you & your ability at the game. I won't act like I've never gotten mad at this game before, but at the end of the day I can't say it was anything other than my own ability at the game. This game also has more content in it than most AAA games that release. You've got the intro levels, N++ (the level category), legacy, race, co-op (the co-op levels are their own thing & require team-work) & many many more. This isn't just some filler crap either to bloat the game, these are all based around the core platforming.  All in all, I recommend this game heavily. Hell if you're on my friend list there's a good chance I'll probably gift you N++ one day whenever I have some cash to spare. I mean for fucks sake, it's 15 dollars & this game could theoretically last you a lifetime so just buy it.

Boy, is this game hard.  Not like your typical type hard, it's diabolical.  It starts you off easy and then immediately goes straight into the ass plunging.  You think you're good?  Think again.  This game redefines what it means to be a good video game player.  Take your sissy pants off, get on your hazmat gear, and get to grinding.  I've screamed in angry delight many times and have easily clocked 6000+ deaths, and yet, I'm still playing.  Am I ret@ard?  Probably.  Am I sane?  Not likely.  But I can assure you that any person with a mental illness will heavily enjoy this game.  If you have OCD, then you'll probably rip your hair out after the 30th hour of gameplay, but who needs hair anyways, it's overrated.

The long of the short, get this game if you like insanely difficult, yet satisfying 2d platforming action.  Yes, you will collect plenty of gold, none of which you can keep in the real life.  And yes, you will die, countless times.  Your ego will be bruised, tattered, and perhaps obliterated as a result of this game.  You think waiting behind a standstill in rush-hour is frustrating, try getting all of the gold in a difficult level and dying seconds before the exit.  It'll bring your pi$$ INSTANTLY to a boil.  But yet....again, I keep playing.....why?!?  Why God?  Why must I be punished in such a sickly enjoyable way.

Ramblings aside, get this game.  Don't be a loser.  Stop standing on the sidelines hoping that you'll one day grow the balls to handle this ride, because it just ain't going to happen.  Pull out your wallet, get your $hit together, and shoot for the stars.  And if you don't reach them, at least you'll hit a strategically placed mine or rocket along the way.  HIGHLY RECOMMEND!

Pros

Platforming perfection with a fantastic soundtrack.

If you're a pseudo-masochist and love tight, momentum based physics, this game is definitely for you. 

The biggest difference between the physics in this game and physics in many other platformers is that you aren't remotely floaty - everything you do carries momentum and has weight to it. It's fun to control without being obnoxiously frustrating at times like Super Meat Boy's "i'm a Need for Speed sports car" physics.

If you don't think that's the kind of physics you're looking for, but you're still interested, try the original freeware N v1.4 or N v2.0 before buying. They're both rough around the edges, obviously, but the physics are exactly the same as N++.

As a revamp to one of my favorite platformer of all time, this is a welcome sequel. 

Needs online multiplayer though.

This game is freakin' great. I played through the the free game and N+, way back, but this is the best version for sure. N++ is so damn hard!! But it's also fair:
 - The controls and precision are exemplary, some of the best ever
 - Every level is deterministic, so you can really practice your route
 - The difficulty curve is nicely done, and the game teaches you tricks as you play through it
 - The level design is often brilliant and there's tons of variety despite the fairly modest number of mechanisms in the game. Students of "game design" will enjoy N++ at an intellectual level.
 - Even the super hidden crazy challenges are all carefully thought out, so you're always confident it's possible.

It was a blast to get good at the game and to move around in the hyperdangerous levels like a ninja. I unlocked Mysteriousness (and did a few secret challenges), which was enough for me, and it took 48 hours of game time (though that is an overestimate since I had to leave the game on mid-episode while I did something else a few times). There's probably at least double that in the game, if I really wanted to punish myself. :)

Downsides:
 - There are a couple of great songs on the soundtrack, but a lot of the music felt a bit too sparse/repetitive to me.
 - I don't like re-treading ground, and it's definitely possible to get yourself stuck by playing to the last level of an episode but not having enough time left to finish it. (I did this on E-19, which was quite annoying.) The fact that you can't restart an episode is part of what draws you in and punishes you into getting better, but IMO the game shouldn't let you get *stuck*.
 - I hate rockets!
 - On Windows it doesn't seem to work if I unplug my joystick and plug a new one in while the game is running. This was a practical issue since I broke one playing the game (!), and then needed to switch to keyboard controls to not lose my progress...
