[h1]N++ is one of the best platformers ever that suffers from a lack of polish, funding, and a few major poor design choices.[/h1]

[h2]Pros[/h2]
[list]
[*] Excellent platformer with a lot of history, soul, and style. Feels just the right amount of floaty with a lot of ability for expression through movement.
[*] Ridiculous amount of depth to movement, especially for something as simple as a game with only three buttons (left, right, jump).
[*] Many mechanics and enemies actually have some of their own depth too, even though on the surface they appear quite straightforward. Rockets are actually phenomenal and super interesting.
[*] Absurdly impressive amount of levels and stuff to do; 100%ing N++ is a difficult task, and takes most people around 800 hours minimum
[*] Episodes/levels are structured in a way that results in you always having something to do or to strive for. Along with community levels, if you want to play N++, you will always have something you can do at any skill level.
[*] The ability to not be able to do something no matter how hard you try, then come back much later after you've gotten better and nail it in a few attempts is a constant. few other games make me feel as good as I do when that happens
[*] Amazing soundtrack
[*] Tons of levels, customization, color palettes
[/list]

[h2]Cons[/h2]
[h3]General[/h3]
[list]
[*] Songs do not have permanent license with the game, so at some point songs will be removed from the game in patches. This has already happened. [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2990677762]You can downpatch to get the music back though.[/url]
[*] The soundtrack is also not for sale anywhere. If you want to buy the entire soundtrack, you'd have to go to multiple different Bandcamps and websites to purchase all the tracks (some of them are not even publicly available anymore btw). After all of that, you'd probably be down about $200. [spoiler]slsk is a good program![/spoiler]
[*] [b]Secret challenges[/b]. Holy fuck, the intended system for these SUCKS. I'll just link [url=https://gamefaqs.gamespot.com/pc/186604-n-plus-plus/faqs/76503]this guide[/url] because explaining it means the review hits the character limit. TL;DR, It's esoteric, annoying, absurdly difficult, and time-wasting. The actual challenges are fun (usually), but discovering them is not.
[*] Some levels/secret challenges are total misses. SU-X-02-04 "losing ground" is one solid example; it's 60 seconds of nothing and then the actual hard part. [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tbtEJ2Ckxw4]"temerity" G--T++ is 60 seconds of pure waiting.[/url]
[*] Episodes sometime seem randomly scattered around without much thought for difficulty and progression.
[/list]
[h3]Multiplayer[/h3]
[list]
[*] There is NO ingrained online multiplayer. The only multiplayer you can do is Steam Remote Play which means that your friend's save does not progress while yours does. [b]So in order for a Co-Op pair to fully complete N++ on their respective machines, you MUST do all of Co-Op TWICE[/b] (which is a monumental task). There is also a Race mode which was built around multiplayer, which has the same issue. Thankfully, you can complete this solo but it takes all of the fun out of the mode. It's best to do this with multiple friends but... good luck with that.
[*] Community is hit or miss. To complete Co-Op, you're basically required to join the official Discord to find another player to play with, and even then you have to find someone who's willing to progress on YOUR save file AND who is also in a region close enough to you to not cause significant input delay. As time passes, this just becomes harder and harder of a task.
[*] On a related note, the Official Discord community can be quite awful. I've seen some of the 100%ers tell minors to kill themselves while mods don't give a shit. Multiple users made fun of a 14y/o kid who used emojis in his messages "too often". There's this one extremely self-hating dude named Renard who made it his life's mission to annoy and harass me (spoiler alert: he just hated himself so he lashed out at a stranger). Some people are just straight up [i]strange[/i]. It's something you don't want to actively involve yourself in; if you're looking for a sense of community, go literally anywhere else. I'm not going to say there AREN'T nice people there (there were a couple of nice people I enjoyed talking to, s/o Emmoji, Doc, xela, Nova, and eyre), but it's the best of a bad bunch.
[/list]
[h3]QoL[/h3]
[list]
[*] Cannot bind multiple keys to one action. This is important for some late game mashing that is required for certain secret challenges.
[*] No option to save all successful replays. Which is really lame. Incredibly useful since you might wanna replay a successful secret challenge attempt but your all-gold run overrides it because it's technically a better score and therefore doesn't save.
[*] No option to replay your latest death.
[/list]
[h3]Bugs[/h3]
[list]
[*] [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1821198112]Saves have a tendency to corrupt.[/url] Saves tend to not work with the Steam Cloud, and it's recommended to keep the Cloud off. You need to keep manual backups, as your save can corrupt for no reason at any time. The game does not keep backups for you. In 348 hours, it hasn't happened to me, but it could at any moment.
[*] [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4nuKuqh7b3M]Your dead body colliding with enemies can destroy your ears because parts can become stuck inside of enemies.[/url]
[*] Can't view replays during an episode. Apparently, you weren't supposed to be able to view a replay of a level before you beat the episode either (which you can). I really don't like this, because you either view the replay for a level you can't figure out or you just look it up on YouTube. The extra intended barrier just does not seem appealing from a player's standpoint.
[*] Profile menu has a bug where it won't display progress correctly.
[*] [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2566075839]Issues displaying on certain high resolutions[/url]
[*] [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3266759653]Game will display sharper on certain languages[/url] (German is sharper compared to English)
[*] Replays are 5.5% slower than actual gameplay. I experienced this odd bug when I tried to make a video syncing a replay with a game recording's audio.
[*] Extremely loud on first launch (as in, when you first install the game)
[/list]

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
This game is phenomenal. I know it sounds like I hate it, but I really just hate aspects of it. I wouldn't have put 350 hours into something that I didn't enjoy. N++ is a great game, but it makes a couple decisions that have me scratching my head trying to wonder what they were thinking at points. It's got a couple of really screwed up and strange bugs, a mostly fucked up community, and a serious lack of some QoL features.

Hi! You don't need to read all of this, I wrote it after 100%ing the game when I was still very emotionally vulnerable (and hormonally everywhere, as growing up will do to you). I'm keeping it all here because it snapshots my feelings really well, but tl;dr:

It is the world's best platformer, for real. There [i]really is[/i] nothing else like this.
Anyways, here's the rest:

It's difficult to explain my experience with this game.
Yes, it's what it is on the tin: the most refined pure platforming experience ever made. It's good. It's really, really, unnecessarily long, but almost every single aspect of the gameplay is perfect. And yet, a part of me still kind of hates it, even if it was me who decided that I should go all the way to the end. Its hugeness can be really imposing on the rest of your Steam library, and its slowness can dissuade a player from leaving the game alone for too long, lest they become unadjusted from it.
(I did 100% it, as you can tell by the obscene hourcount, but it wasn't as severe as it first might appear: that was over the course of four years. In reality, it amounted to about one or two hours a day - though, knowing myself, it's more like that the days I chose to play, I averaged three.)
Let's go back a bit. It's impossible to describe the experience I had without going back to where I first discovered N++ specifically - betatesting the Mac version of the game (and I'm so so so sorry for that one terrible bug, I really should have said something about it or at least noticed it sooner) via a public thread on the Steam forums. One thing leads to another, and I end up in the Discord server for the game. I don't think there's any other game where you can actively document your progress, share your custom maps and access a broad highscoring platform for literal years in the same way N++ does. And, to be honest, I hope there never is. The community is wonderful over there, but I think after so much, I can only feel exhausted. I don't have much left to say about it. I started when I was 14, and I'm 18 now.
Mare and Raigan are wonderful people, by the way. I'm not! Thanks for putting up with me.
Wait, this is a review, I'm supposed to talk about the actual game.
Well, the main campaign, aka the "N++ tab" is perfect. The Ultimate tab is a bit less interesting to me personally, but I think it has moments that justify the doubling of the size of the game. Legacy feels somewhat vestigal, though. I'm not really a fan of the episode structure, either; I had much more fun with the [spoiler]nonlinear insanity that is the two secret tabs, ESPECIALLY the latter.[/spoiler]. As for [spoiler]the thousands of "secret challenges", aka "complete the level [i]like this[/i][/spoiler], I would say... there's a very big portion that are good, and a slightly smaller but still noticable section that are "just okay". There isn't really anything in the game that I would say compares to any major challenge in another game, it's just a very, very big slope of difficulty.
There's also a "Hardcore mode" in the game where you complete 25 levels in a row with time carrying over. There are completion points for doing these deathless. I hated it, because the way the levels are structured make all of the 65 "hardcore stories" have backloaded difficulty. It wasn't fun, and although people tell me that I'm not justified because I highscored many of them as I did the nodeath, I felt personally that if I didn't do something to keep myself occupied as I tried this, I would probably go insane.
Co-op and Race are extremely fun. Use Parsec and find a good partner on the Discord.
Userlevels by the community in general are very good, but the ones you'll see in Newest currently are occupied by (possibly more than one) braindead child who was left alone with a Nintendo Switch, ALMOST EVERY DAY. (Seriously, please just fucking get rid of him. I'm not going to be subtle about this, this isn't worth anyone's while.) Besides that, I'm happy to have met so many talented artists, architects and otherwise. They have definitely inspired me, more than the server probably understands.
The game only has UI bugs, no gameplay bugs. But the UI bugs the game has, and the one major bug on the Mac version, happen to be so massively inconvenient it can be heartbreaking sometimes - because the game is otherwise so good. I played 90% of the game on a now decade-old laptop, so that should tell you about what the game can handle. It's extremely optimized C++ code - you'll have a good time playing and the devs would literally have to go to hell and back to fix anything. Including the 100% achievements. God fucking damn it, I feel bad because I was supposed to help fix that, too. Maybe I'll do it after writing this review.

tl;dr It's a rollercoaster. Don't play it if you value your Steam achievements (f++king get over it, nobody cares). Don't play it if you intend to finish everything you touch, in fact, don't even play it if you intend to finish it. This game screams "a hardcore platformer intended to be played casually, even when some of the challenges are definitely not obtainable by causally playing through the game with no attention". If that's not your cup of tea - [i]if you don't even really like platformers[/i] - just don't play it. It's a game. Play for fun.
has, like, THE best motion mechanics of any game ive ever played. super simple controls, practically no learning curve, but definitely challenging to say the least.

N++ is one of the greatest platformer's I have ever played. It's not the best game on steam for any one particular thing. It doesn't have the deepest, most tear-jerking story on the market. It doesn't have the most insane mechanics with the highest ceiling of technical skill. It doesn't have a soundtrack or art that keeps you staring in awe. It's just a simple platformer. Collect coins, avoid death, get to the end. Sounds boring? No.

That's what makes it perfect.

N++ is just a platformer, but it does that aspect REALLY well. It feels fluid, smooth, and easy to pick up. N++ has easy enough levels to ease newbies to the genre, and fun level design that keeps casuals playing. But it also has some insanely difficult levels with high precision, or the option to 100% complete the game or speedrun levels fighting for highscore for hardcore veterans of the genre. If you enjoy platformers, you'll enjoy N++.  Sometimes, making a game that appeals to a wider audience reduces from what makes the game unique. N++ would be less of a game if it had a deep story, less fun if it had extra crazy movement tech. N++ doesn't overstretch what it is, because sometimes jack-of-all-trades is less interesting and unique, and your core audience will enjoy it less.

The soundtrack is often very minimal, only supplementing the gameplay, which is perfect for the vibe the game was attempting to portray. The art is mainly color schemes, and there's a lot of them (personally use the dark mode a lot.) All of this is done to highlight the gameplay itself, and rather than subtracting from it, all of these work with it to further enhance it. It's a big step up from N and N+ some 20 years ago.

But a platformer is only as good as the levels it's built on. And there it also shines. The levels are charming, and with a level-editor, it always has room for more improvement. The amount of levels you get at the BASE level is already insanely high, adding more via level-editor and sharing them with friends or others always feels fun.

N++ is, simply put, the epitome of good platforming. Platformer incarnate. If I ever want to suggest a platformer to someone, and don't know their taste in games, N++ is the first one to come to mind.

One of the most refined, pure gameplay-focused platformers in existence. The momentum feels amazing. There's no end to the levels. N++ is the definitive one, but try the free version if you're unsure. It's a classic.
